We swore off this place after being ignored by the hostess one time too many (while there were lots of tables open) and a couple of other times being seated but it taking forever to get our order in.  Why do they ignore us?  I have no idea.  But sometimes the staff just seems to be in a bad mood.

Anyway, we've taken our business to Sushi Suki down the street, a family run place with fresh sushi and awesome prices.  If they are rude to you at Fuji, never fear, just head down the block :)
author: R P.

description:
I came here a couple days ago with a friend. It was my probably my fourth time eating here. 

The food was really good and the sashimi was really fresh. My favorite rolls are the Liger and the Dinosaur Foot.

Service was amazing. The staff is really friendly and attentive, even the people who cut the fish!
author: Derek T.

description:
Yummmmyyyyyy!!! The baked scallop roll, liger roll, and baked mussels are my go tos!!! The fish is super fresh and the customer service is wonderful! I always leave happy and full :) 

Bring cash for that extra 10% off your bill!!!
author: Michelle H.

description:
I can't recall the last time I ate here, but we came yesterday for lunch.  We were pleasantly surprised with our bento boxes.  I liked my California rolls. Six pieces and thick avocado slices but hardly any crab. My shrimp vegetable tempura was good but only one shrimp?

Is $10.95 pricey for a bento box? And $1.50 for green tea?

Three couples and separate checks with restaurant imposed 20% gratuity. Huh?

$32.00.   

If it weren't for the price, I would come more often.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Don't expect a warm welcome or much else beside the fish to be stellar and you'll enjoy Fuji just fine. 

The fish is really really fresh. The salad I had with my bento box was kind of a mushy mess and visually unappealing. The oil the tempura was fried in was probably due for a change. The waitstaff was pretty checked out, but it was late in the day for lunch and early for dinner so they probably just weren't feeling it. 

Not many sushi places have fresher fish though, so I'd go again and think you'd probably enjoy it too.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
I find the prices here to be a bit ridiculous. Portions are really small and some of the items seems thrown together without much thought. 

The fish was fresh and everything we ate was good but I left hungry even though I ordered more than I usually would. 

I wouldn't eat here again.
author: Emma M.

description:
This. Place. Sucks.

A "good safety" warning popped up when I yelped it, wish I'd seen it sooner. One waitress who is CONSTANTLY overwhelmed. Took forever to get my order taken, even longer to get it served, and she served several tables that had been seated after me. Horribly unprofessional. Don't waste your time.
author: P M.

description:
Pretty good food, expensive though. 

We ordered some nigiri - some assorted platter of it. I think there were 8 or 9 pieces of various types of fish (I don't really remember which ones). We also ordered a rainbow roll and something similar to Lion King roll (California roll with salmon baked on top and with some sauce), but the one we ordered had scallops and seriously, it was delicious. The date ended up eating more than half of it. Damn him. 

Overall, we had a great time there, even if it was expensive. Sushi isn't all that cheap though, so I understood.
author: Nina Y.

description:
The Dinosaur Foot is the bomb. No. It's better than that. It's the asteroid that killed the dinosaurs. But don't worry, it doesn't taste anything like what I'd imagine an actual dinosaur foot would taste like. It's very unique. Not very large (only four pieces), but I think it's totally worth it. I get it every time.

The Mt. Fuji Roll is also great. A little spicy, but not so spicy that you'll get heartburn or hot butthole later on. My boyfriend always gets the Finding Nemo and he loves it.

It's a little pricier than other sushi places we go to, but I wouldn't say that it's overpriced. And it's in West Portal, which is just so damn cute that it's always nice to have an excuse to head on over to those parts.
author: Stephenie S.

description: Grand reopening, but the foods did not. Just had their bento box and salmon does not taste fresh. The tempura was way too oily. Everything tasted way to salty? Ask for dressing on the side, but came back drenches with sauces...
author: Melvon M.

description:
This place charges little too much for its quality. The sushi was ok, they used to be better.
I was very disappointed with their uninvolved service( its my 3rd time experiencing ). We're Korean and most of the customers there were non-Korean or Caucasian. The waitress was not so nice to us, but incredibly friendly to Caucasian. 
Also minus one star for the sticky table.

I feel bad giving a two-star review but there are many things they would need  to improve.
author: Helena K.

description: Folks this place is the "gold standard" for a neighborhood Japanese restaurant. The quality of the food, especially the fish (sushi and sashimi,) is top notch. Their lunch time bento is what a bento should be. Generous portions, good taste, fresh quality, and decent price. Their rolls, although a bit expensive (compared to other Korean owned Japanese restaurants,) are delicious, big, well made, and satisfying. (Dragon Roll=A+. Chicken teriyaki/nigiri sushi two item lunch combo (#B set) is the bomb!! The restaurant is not that big and a bit busy at lunch time, and since this is a normal upper middle class residential area, this place is relatively "hipster free. " (if that's okay with you!)
author: George F.

description: After coming here several more times I give them 5 stars. Their service is always great. The portions are small and pricey but that's fine. I eat less with age.
author: Keit K.

description: All the staffs are very nice and great customer service. Food is high quality and taste amazing! They have great lunch specials and dinner boxes. Bunch of menu selections of choices. I love mango roll (semi-sweet & fresh red tuna, on top of shrimp tempura roll. Also Dino foot is also amazing!!! Love it love it. You must try this spot because it's the best sushi place in town.
author: Stella K.

description: I am fresh out of giving this place the benefit of the doubt. I have lived in the neighborhood for 12 years and have come to Fuji at least five different times. Each time I patronized this place, I felt that the service was super slow, and the attitudes of the servers left a lot to be desired. Regarding the sushi, I have no complaints, it was average to a bit above. The last straw for me was when they shut down and I discovered their repeated history of health violations dating back annually to 2010. I now feel their lack of detailed attention to the many heath violations reflects that they they didn't care about me or my health all along.  My Wife and I will never go there again.
author: A D.

description:
I feel bad writing a two-star review as my non-fish-eating Boo brought me here as a treat. Of course, he had the chicken teriyaki bento box and offloaded the salmon and tuna sashimi and the shrimp tempura on me. 

I ordered my usual litmus test sushi food as follows:

Agedashi tofu - mediocre. Over-cooked and lying in a puddle of juice - no bonito, no daikon, a little red ginger. Chipped dish. Needed a spoon too. Fail.

Ikura - good and fresh. Win.

Amaebi - didn't seem too fresh, and they tried to disguise the fact with some tobiko on to. Fried heads were overcooked. Fail.

Sea trout - lovely. Win. (It was the special, so it should have been fresh!)

Natto - Win just because they had it. It was pretty good. 

The salmon and tuna sashimi was okay. Not the freshest I've had, but it was okay. The shrimp tempura was good. 

The service was friendly but a little slow - good thing we weren't in a hurry or anything - but it took them a good 10 minutes to take our order and another 5 minutes to bring drinks. I don't mind slow service if I have a drink in front of me - it was Friday night after all!

I peeked at the bill and it seemed kind of high for what we had.
author: Mi M.

description:
I've been here for 20 mim maybe more, and they just took our order. The table next to us is getting there starters and they arrived after we got here.
The food was okay... All in all. It's over priced with slow service.
author: Kenneth C.

description:
Just came here last night...the quality of the sushi is declining fast.

I ordered the Finding Nemo roll and Salmon Skin hand roll. The Finding Nemo was falling apart before I even picked it up. I also noticed how much SMALLER it was this time around...two pieces of the roll last night would have equaled to ONE piece of a sushi roll from the Fuji that I used to love. As for the salmon skin hand roll....the key ingredient to the salmon skin hand roll is the crunchiness of the salmon skin. It wasn't crunchy at all and it was oily and soggy.

My Mom ordered the dinner bento box with the grilled hamachi/yellowtail. It was tasteless, rough, and not grilled well. A FAR cry from the crispy, well-grilled hamachi that used to come with dinner boxes before.

Also - did you guys change chefs? I noticed the chefs this time around were a lot younger
author: Angel A.

description: Another exemplary dining experience. Native SF local rates Fuji as #1 dining area not just in west portal but sf!!! Shannon and Joseph keep the family tradition alive. Great good, great service.  A+ K is the best service in SF.
author: John C.

description:
Ugh. Before sitting down I watched the staff swirl a dirty rag over the table and over the placemats...without picking them up.  At least she could pretend to spray some cleaner on the table. 
The service is slow and it does not appear that they care. We have been going for years, and I've watched it go downhill. The food is ok, but I wonder about the cleanliness in the kitchen. Sad.
author: Catherine C.

description:
Oh hell yeah. In the pics of this spot they got my favorite roll, the Mango roll. They got some good creative rolls here. Fuji is one of my fav Sushi spots but even when I come here with people that don't eat sushi I rec the tempura and their teriyaki dishes. 

Its easy to rack up your bill while just sample all the different rolls. Damn 2 of us almost went to a hundred but man did we freaking eat good that day. There's only one other Sushi place I really like on par with this and I gotta do a review of them soon. 

This is one of those places where the food comes out looking nice and all pretty that is actually good. The portions ain't small either. I like the place its cozy but not hella small. The servers are nice and if you ask what people like they'll tell ya.
author: T C.

description: Pricey, yet so disappointing. We ordered the chicken and the katsu donburi and both were very basic, yet terrible.  The katsu was wet and chewy, not crispy like usual, and the chicken was pretty bland.  The rice was very mushy as well. Nowhere near worth the high price. Ugh.
author: David T.

description: The food is good. Suggest the liger roll.  But service is way too long I waited 45 minutes for one roll and this was lunch time and it wasn't even busy . The chefs u can see making sushi there's two and they just kind of take their time and talk to each other . iv always waited over 30 minutes here to get one to two sushi rolls . its wayyyy too long . But the liger roll is delicious
author: Lara C.

description: Went to this place for the first time this week, the food was delicious the restaurant itself gives off a very warm ambiance which I appreciated, their sashimi is fresh and their cooked products are tasty . Staff was friendly I will definitely be coming back
author: Yoshi Y.

description: It is not inventive. Not inspiring. Typical Japanese menu with no flair.  I try it once a year and wonder why I go back.
author: Goldie N.

description: Very good place in the neighborhood, relative to a few other places in the area, quality of fish is better. The prices are decent. Parking is pretty easy around west portal.
author: Shannon J.

description:
Came here with my fam since the wait at Ebisu was 1 1/2 hours.

+spicey crunch roll
+sea weed salad
+West 14th

MmMMMmmmm.... suuuuushiiiii

mmMMmmmmmm sake!

Id probably come here to try a box?

Service: moderate
author: Julia D.

description: I was disappointed with the service.  I didn't have all the time in the world but I would've liked to have given my order within the first 10 minutes of sitting down.  It took awhile for the girl to get to the front and she was the only one working.  I couldn't wait any longer so I got up and left.  I could usually be patient if I see that there is not that many workers but it was ridiculous.
author: Chrissie O.

description:
Salmon sashimi was delicious. 49er roll was also delicious other than the fact that it was poorly rolled so when I picked it up, it fell apart. 
Wouldn't recommend the udon, it was bland, lacked flavor and boring.
Bento box w/chicken teriyaki, tempura, gyoza and sashimi was good.
author: Meuy S.

description:
The service here SUCKS!!!
Our reservation was for 6:30 & we were on time. It wasn't until past 7pm when after we flagged them down TWICE, did they finally take our order!!! It'd be a joke if they expect a tip after the horrible service we're currently getting.
author: Alex C.

description: Place is great, always order lunch pick up one a week or every other week. Food is great tried dining in for dinner on a Friday night not to bad of a wait but the waiter forgot a few things we ordered like our drinks and etc. which sucked cause it was still on the bill but overall i still would recommend this place sashimi is worth it!
author: William N.

description:
Really wonderful Sushi! Good service. Generous portions. The Fish is very fresh and they have unique rolls that are delicious!
My first time... Can't wait till next time :)
author: Niloufer H.

description: Not very happy with their service. I was sitting there for 20 minutes but no one greeted me. The lunch is crappy compared with other places nearby. Price does not match quality and service.
author: Lin Y.

description: HORRIBLE SERVICE! It was my birthday and we requested to switch table cuz our first table was breathing down the neck of our neighbors. Then the two servers were rude and we're talking shit on my group right in front us. I was very upset because it was my BIRTHDAY NEVER GOING BACK
author: Jenny H.

description:
I've eaten here a number of times and always found it to be good fresh sushi.  Not sure if i wasn't paying as much attention previously, or if the prices went up, but I was surprised how expensive if was this past time.  We ordered a good bottle of sake this time, but even taking that out of the bill, the sushi was still about $90 for two of us for thee rolls and an assorted sashimi.  

I enjoy that they serve the sake in a wood bowl.  The wood enhances the sake and makes it fun.

I'll probably go back again, but I'm going to watch the bill more closely next time.
author: William N.

description:
This is my first Yelp review ever and probably my last. 

When I have a bad experience or eat horrible food its usually just a lesson learned and I move on and don't ever go back. However, the food at this is place is so absolutely horrendous and disgusting that I feel obligated to write a review. If you are looking for traditional Japanese style FRESH FISH NO NOT go here. I ordered three rolls and the toro. The Toro sill had plastic from the wrapper is came in and smelled like a can of tuna. The first roll I ordered also had the smell of fish and I literally spit it out of my mouth and into my napkin after I chewed into it. 

I have literally eaten sushi all over the world at approx 100 or so different sushi restaurants and this place is without a doubt the absolute worse. 

The prices are what should be charged at a good restaurant which also adds to the horrible review. 

I cannot for the life of me understand how people give this place above one star but in my opinion it is the worst sushi (i am amazed they even call it sushi) I have ever had.

Take this review for what its worth.
author: Gilbert G.

description:
We usually eat at Fresca in the West Portal neighborhood but tonight we felt like trying something new and my fiancé had the urge for sushi so we decided to stop in this joint after we drove by.

We ordered a couple of sushi rolls, a hand roll and a Sea Bass Gindara dish.

I would have to describe this place as a more expensive version of Kiki Sushi (Sunset) or Kitaro   
(Richmond).  The rice in all the sushi dishes were over cooked and the ratio of rice and fish were not up to par (way too much rice).

This isn't a place I would ever go back nor would i recommend it to any friends.  

Plenty of Japanese Sushi restaurant in San Francisco and you would not miss anything if you don't come here.
author: C Y.

description: Good food but service slower than a turtle running through peanut butter.  Don't come here if you're in a rush or want a refill on your drink at any type of decent speed.
author: Megan S.

description: I just left this place feeling very frustrated. I came in and waited then asked "excuse me can I sit at the bar or order to go?" The hostess says "hold on a minute while I help them" then walks past me to help people who came AFTER me. I try to tell her this. She ignores, Sears them and says in a rude voice "you want take out? We have a lot of to go orders now" as she continues to ramble and act annoyed that I might want to spend my money there I stop her and say "never mind I'll go somewhere else. It's sad because I've been wanting to try this place for a while. I will NOT be going back!
author: Maria H.

description:
Nice small little restaurant. Pretty big servings, but a bit pricey. 

Food is tasty, got the chicken teriyaki, california roll, and spicy tuna roll. The complementary salad is also yummy. 

Come if you're in the area and want Japanese. But there are better places out there.
author: Jenny E.

description: If you are expecting high end sushi this is not it.  If you are expecting low end sushi this is not it.  It is just a relatively quiet place, with some creative rolls, and a decent ambiance.  If you are in a rush I wouldn't go, but if you are in the neighborhood and have some time stop by.
author: Channing S.

description: Ehhh. I had the specials - bluefin tuna nigiri and toro nigiri. Neither were worth the price tag. The toro was 20 dollars for two pieces. I would happily pay anything for amazing toro (ie- ebisu in the sunset).. But this left me with the feeling that I'd been jipped. I'm sure their rolls are great but because the fish isn't the highest quality I wouldn't get the pricy specials.
author: Jessie L.

description:
I can't review the food since I wasn't even able to buy it. I ordered a California Roll and found out when I got there that they have a $15 minimum for credit card payment (which is in violation of the Visa merchant agreement). I told them I would buy my sushi somewhere else and they said "okay" and let me walk out the door. I literally walked across the street and got a California Roll from their competitor moments later.

To the owner: looking at the reviews on Yelp it doesn't seem like your food is so good that you can throw potential customers away. I won't be returning here again.

For reference, the Visa merchant agreement states:

Minimum Purchase
U.S. retailers may require a minimum purchase amount on credit card transactions. The minimum purchase amount must not exceed $10 and does not apply to transactions made with a debit card. [which I was attempting to use for payment]
author: Drew L.

description: Fish is very fresh. Service is outstanding. Shannon the owner is super accommodating and a pleasure to shoot sake with.  Great upstairs room with TV to watch games. My go to sushi spot.
author: Deirdre L.

description: Went with my sister during their lunch break, but they still accepted us! Very social and nice workers that kept us company at the sushi bar. In addition, the food was very very good. Salmon sashimi melted in my mouth, while the liger roll had harmonious flavors (the green onion wasn't overwhelming or anything). The sashimi salad was very fresh too, highly recommend it! Will come back :)
author: Kevin T.

description:
Food was meh. Sashimi is ok fresh, but the sushi rice is disappointing. The rice texture lacks the vinegar taste and is somewhat too hard. 

Grilled Miso Gindara was small and not warm when served. There are plenty of Americanized rolls to choose from in the menu. The highlight of the meal for me is Hokkaido Hotate which is fresh and tasty.
author: Saran R.

description:
The servers there can be a bit un friendly, I guess they have a lean staff and are over worked.
Tables are hit and miss - Usually they are clean but sometimes you may get sticky unclean table.
What I noticed is that its a very popular place ( For Good sushi) and hence they are always busy leading to unhappy tired servers and sticky table
Try them on a weekday mid week or so, you may catch a similing server.
I have been going there for over 6 yrs and I love that place.
author: Food C.

description: Came here with a party of 7.  This place is good for sushi rolls--they are big and the thickness of the fish on the rolls are generous compared to other sushi restaurants.  We were dissapointed with the sashimi though (only about 4 types of fish selection I expected more for $20 or so).  Downstairs ambience  is good, but upstairs is like an old attic--very dark upstairs and seriously need a simple remodel/paint job and getting rid of all the junk and the old shelves against the wall.  Also, they automatically add 20% tip into the bill--and this is not a high-end restaurant and their service is not like superb.  They should let customers decide how much to tip.
author: tomcat f.

description:
i've actually been coming here for more than 10 years.  good sushi spot on west portal... i really should say great because it's about 5 minutes from my house.  overall fresh sushi and decent to large sized servings for how much you pay.  

i kind of knocked it down one star because there are just too many different rolls to choose from here.  why is that a bad thing? because it takes people (that i'm usually eating with) even longer to pick something to eat, and of course, i'm starving.
author: Tina L.

description: I ordered California Rolls and it tasted quite soggy and it tasted bland even with the soy sauce. Delivery was fast. Expensive.
author: Sally Y.

description: My wife and I go here often and it is amazing. You get what you pay for here and the service is great as well. Small dining room but they have an upstairs and are really close to muni and west portal station. Great food, good prices
author: John B.

description: I would recommend only coming for lunch. Otherwise the prices are a bit unreasonable. I ordered the Chicken Teriyaki and an order of CA rolls (artificial crab is a dollar cheaper) The chicken was a hefty portion and very well cooked and tasty. I opted for extra salad instead of rice and the salad is amazing here. I loved the sesame dressing and bits of sugar roasted sunflower seeds. I also liked the fruit they paired with my chicken (very fresh) The miso soup was probably the worst item that came with my meal. One small piece of seaweed and barely any tofu. The Ca rolls are just okay and my friends maki rolls were kind of gross. Overall an ok stop for lunch but I don't see myself returning here anytime soon.
author: Kristy F.

description:
The udon was packed with vegetables!  Besides that, this place didn't have much going for it.  The yellowtail wasn't very good.  Chicken teriyaki was acceptable, but nothing to write home about (or brag on Yelp about).

Came in for lunch at 2pm and within 5 minutes of sitting down at the bar, the staff started cleaning everything up to close. Once they finished breaking down, they paced in our peripherals until we finished, paid, and left.  It was very unsettling.  We hit the sidewalk at 2:30.  It was then that I saw the sign on the door that said they closed at 2:30.  I mean, I get it.  I wouldn't like to have to wait around for one table either, but they could have mentioned that when we walked in, or they could've not been jerks.  Either way would have been preferred.
author: Denise K.

description: They don't have enough wait staff, and with the limited staffing, they really don't know how to prioritize their limited people power, which all translates to really poor service.
author: Jay C.

description:
Personally, I've been here a few times myself.

The food is decent, but the service can teeter-totter a bit:

The Sushi Chefs are awesomely cool guys!!!

But addressing concerns of other reviews from Asian customers, the waitresses do seem to treat Caucasian customers better. And I have absolutely no idea why...

I made friends with a Caucasian gentleman while sitting at the Sushi Bar. Really nice guy.

But when he asked for draught, service with a smile from the waitress. When I asked for a draught, the lady turned around with a "what do YOU want" look on her face. Pretty much just gave me my beer and walked away....??? Weird, no?

And my new Caucasian friend was out and paid for in a matter of minutes in regards to the bill...

I sat around twiddling my thumbs waiting for the bill, then waiting to pay for it!!! WTF, right!?!?

The Beef Teri was decent, and the Sushi was good.

Only reason I'd really go back is to hang out with the Sushi Chefs. And that's saying alot from someone who usually only goes to Japanese owned Sushi Restaurants.

Overall still a good place, but the waitresses really gotta get over their racial complexes. Maybe the majority of waitresses there are not like that, but this is just my experience there as an American man from Asian descent.
author: J M.

description:
Wonderful place to enjoy fancy Japanese sushi !
The freshness of sasimi and sushi is the best ever I had in California. I strongly recommend this place to have a date with your girl friend or boy friend.
author: Winston L.

description: I went eat sushi on Sunday man I waited one hour to get my damn sushi. Damn sushi boy keep talking with his friends. Let me tell u this: If u are making sushi whatever don't talk your saliva spreading everywhere. Seems like they are short staff but he shouldn't  be talking his friends seriously. Disrespectful.
author: Yoki P.

description:
Saw quite a few negative reviews, so had to insert my two cents!

This is my favorite place to go to sushi in all of San Francisco. My friends and I usually order vegetable tempura to start with, and then order a bunch of rolls to share. You really can't go wrong, here, though. Sushi is always fresh, service is good,  and the Thursday night half-off drinks is a nice incentive to go out during the week.

I love Fuji...
author: Nicole T.

description:
We went to have sushi and as a sushi lover who has been to many many sushi restaurant in San Francisco as well as all over Bay Area, I was totally disappointed.

We ordered miso soup . It had a strange after taste of cardboard to it. Then we asked for  an order of nagiri Toro. It was a good size fish but not like other toro nigiri I had before. Toro usually has a buttery taste to it and melts in your mouth. This one had chewy fish membrane  in it and did not feel that fresh ( the two piece we found out later cost us $19.50 which was extremely overpriced). Then we ordered two rolls, a Rock and Roll and a Softshell Crab Roll. They we awful. 

The Rock and Rolls were huge rice rolls with tiny pieces of Unagi and lots of slivers of cucumber. It was impossible to bite on it  as the seaweed wrap was so hard that one could not cut it with the teeth and in addition, due to the size of the roll it was impossible to put the tasteless dry roll in your mouth as a whole. 

Then came the soft shell crab roll. It was even worse. There were tiny pieces of crab legs engulfed in super salty panko breadcrumbs and fried.  These rolls were  again mostly huge amount of tasteless rice and cucumber slivers with a dash of green on the end piece.

When the bill came and we saw how outrageously overprice this restaurant is we were even more disappointed at our choice.

Fuji is a the worse sushi restaurant I have ever been to and is a waste of money.
author: Mahin C.

description: we wanted some good japanese food so we looked up some options in yelp! Fuji in west portal in san francisco came out on top so we tried it. great choice! food was fantastic and meal portions were HUGE! although a little pricey, especially for dinner, FUJI is a great choice.
author: Rick S.

description: So the story of this place is that it used to be good when the couple who ran the place was together. Then they split up, then the quality of the food goes down. The sushi is not fresh, the udon is oily. The service is slow. Very disappointing.
author: Sandie Y.

description:
They had a great stock of sake and sochu, great Japanese menu items and the decor was Japanese like. I think its Korean owned, as the sushi chefs were gossiping in Korean amongst themselves the entire time.

Waitress service is excellent, but if you sit at the counter (as my family of 3 did), don't expect any customer service what so ever from the sushi chefs. At least at a real Japanese restaurant, the sushi chefs ask patrons at the counter (who are sitting right in front of them!) if their food is ok, and if they need anything. Not these guys, they rather gossip to each other in Korean. So un-Japanese!

We ordered all sushi items, where the fish was pretty good quality wise. However, their prices don't quite justify the quality. A little overpriced in my opinion. Their sushi rice needs improvement, falling apart before you can take it with your chopsticks into your mouth. 

Fuji is one of the few Japanese restaurants in the West Portal area. Take it or leave it. For us, we'll leave it. Instead, drive a little down on Monterey Blvd. towards Sunnyside and go to K's Kitchen.
author: Mark M.

description: Not a great experience.  Service was spotty and food was uninspiring.  Can't say I would recommend to folks.
author: Johnson W.

description: Excellent service! The servers were extremely friendly and attentive. The food was also very good! You have to try their liger roll and spicy crunch roll! Would definitely come back and recommend this place to friends and family!
author: Grace T.

description:
Service = efficient.
Decor = simple.  
Food = delicious.  Can't believe in my decade in SF, I never ventured in here... lol Even though God knows I remember waiting for the train across from it........:-X Sashimi, delicious, fresh, and not lukewarm.   Big rolls = not that big but it's very filling and full of good flavor.  Maki rolls = delicious and not mushy seaweed. My favorite handroll, the spicy scallop, passed the test here. Not too creamy, nor covered in bajillion spices...and delicious silky scallop, raw. :D

Prices = you get what you pay for here.  I was pretty happy with my experience here...give it a whirl!  And it seems to be a popular place for families (with children.)
author: Fannie S.

description:
Love, love, LOVEE Fuji's in West Portal! Very welcoming and friendly from the moment you step in the door until you leave. Everyone that works here is very nice and attentive to your needs. And best yet, very fresh fish!

My favorite thing to order at Fuji's, and it's a must order, would be the Dinosaur Foot! It is prepared with spicy tuna red onion, tobiko, eel sauce, honey mayo all on top of a deep fried mint leaf. Trust me, you'll love!

We also enjoy their Beef Teriyaki. Unlike some other Japanese restaurants who over cooked their beef way too much, Fuji's serves some of the best beef teriyaki I've tried. It's very tender and juicy. You can choose how you want it cooked. Others don't even give you the option of letting them know how you like your meat. Their chicken teriyaki is also a good option to go for if you're not a beef kinda person. 

Sushi rolls I love to order from here are as follow.
Liger - Shrimp tempura, salmon, shrimp, avocado, and honey mustard/mayo
Finding Nemo - Salmon and avocado over spicy tuna
Omega 3 - Tuna, Salmon, Escolar, with ponzu sauce
and of course, the Dinosaur Foot!! 

Their bento options are also very affordable and they definitely do not skimp on their portions. Their sashimi in the bento is thick cut and super fresh!

Definitely give Fuji's a shot if you haven't yet. (Dinosaur Foot!)
author: Juliane N.

description: Being born and raised in Seattle, I have always been blessed with great seafood -- it's practically everywhere. But ever since I've moved to San Francisco, I've been constantly on the hunt to find a new sushi restaurant that I could call my go-to. Didn't expect to find it here in West Portal! Fuji, located in a small, kitschy neighborhood, is the place that can cater to all your sushi needs. I always start off with the sashimi sampler and finish solid with the Finding Nemo and Liger roll. The fish is very fresh among the other sushi restaurants I've tried in the city, and the rolls are big enough to share among friends. I've also tried the Rock&Roll, which has a thicker layer of rice on the outside that I love. Be prepared for a true carb feast. I've noticed that most of the reviews teeters between a 3 and 4 star, but don't underestimate this place! It's true, weekends tend to get pretty packed here, so I've noticed that sushi orders tend to take a little longer when its near peak hours, but if you're down for the wait, you won't be disappointed! Other than that, service is great, and I would highly recommend anyone to try this place out.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: I just love this place. Its clean and food is fantastic. Seriously Fresh! But. Very expensive. I get a roll and tea and it's over 20 bucks. Also they charge for hot tea? .99 cents. All in all it's convenient and easily accessible since there is good parking and muni stops on the corner.
author: Mario A.

description:
Actually Korean-owned, but the Koreans take this stuff as seriously as the Japanese do.  

So, if you've read my other reviews, you know I don't go for garbage in my sushi (ie., no mayonnaise please, no ham, pineapple or other stuff that doesn't belong there).  

The good:  Fresh, well-made sushi and sashimi.   The cooked dishes are standard, not outstanding but well prepared.  Great list of Sakes and Shochus, moderate pricing.  Some of the waitresses are really pretty, in case you care about that!  The guys behind the counter are friendly, if you sit at the Sushi bar.

The bad:  A lot of people have focused on stuff like the Dinosaur foot.  I consider that stuff garbage, and wouldn't order it.   Generally, Japanese restaurants that do that kind of crap are bad at the real thing.  In this case, just ignore it and order the real thing. My experience has been fine.  

Usually crowded, but if you are there at a less busy time the service is good.
author: charles h.

description:
Cute little sushi place. Very welcoming, very warm.

I coped a spot at the bar and the friendly bartender/ sushi preparer made me a Avocado maki which was delicious and a Spider roll, that though it seemed to be missing it's regular sauce and crab mix was still quite good.

Their miso was tasty and I saw a sign that they won't serve hot tea to tables with children which I think is a great safety idea.

I'd come back any time.
author: Meg T.

description: Because San Francisco has quite a few sushi places around the same price point, it is only fair to say this one charges too much for its quality. While not strictly bad, the sushi is decently good, but not so much so as to warrant a glowing recommendation.
author: Gilbert L.

description:
We ordered a bunch of stuff that was okay. I ordered the Korean-style chirashi because I wanted to see what it would look like. It's little cubes of (leftover?) sashimi atop a HUGE bed of shredded green leaf and spring mix lettuces drizzled with sesame oil. There was a little mound of rice under the lettuce. You're supposed to mix it up like bibimbop with hot sauce but there is SO MUCH lettuce that it's too messy to do the mix. 

The raw kumamoto oysters were amazing! They come out pre-flavored with a dot of sauce. Add a little lemon and OMG it was perfect.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
After seeing the movie City Island nearby, we popped in here for an after movie meal of sushi, sake and beer.  Since my friend is Japanese, I figured she would be impressed since I've always had good meals here.

I'm not sure if it was an off night or what as I've only been there for lunch and it has been several months since my last visit.

Waitress wasn't too happy (maybe because we walked in 45 minutes before closing?).  She was a bit impatient as my friend asked her about some of the appetizers.  She could have warned us that we were ordering too much food (I never knew their rolls were super sized) and we started getting the stink eye from the crew as they began putting chairs on top of the tables exactly at closing time.

Frankly, we should have been informed that they would expect us to leave exactly at closing time and everybody was in a hurry to go home.  Knowing that, we could have decided whether or not to eat there quickly or go elsewhere in this sleepy little town.  I mentioned this to the owner and he didn't seem to give a sh*t.  No worries as we still had a wonderful evening laughing about how good the movie was.  Go see it.

I don't accept that type of rude behavior from any restaurant and I won't go back as a result of it.  Sayonara baybee.
author: Anthony D.

description: Decent sushi bar. It's good for my sushi crave but don't expect high quality fish. It's basic. But still worthy going.
author: Antonio I.

description:
We've been going to Fuji, a good, solid sushi joint in West Portal, for many years. While not the best in the city, they have good range, fresh fish, inventive rolls and excellent, friendly service. I can't recall having a disappointing meal and have occasionally had very good ones.

They're larger than they look, having a room tucked away upstairs where they can seat larger groups, and they take reservations. So they're a pretty good place for a large-ish dinner.

One of my favorite dishes, by the way, is the Korean chirashi. Worth trying if you're looking for Korean flavors in Korean-food-challenged West Portal!
author: Marc T.

description:
Its been a while since I have not eaten at Japanese restaurant since the very last time I ate at Kamakura.. I have decided to explore another Japanese Restauraant this time I went to go try Fuji for lunch and had myself these items which I have eaten at Fuji during the lunch time hour...


KATSU DONBURI DEEP FRIED PORK CUTLET IN KATSU SAUCE W/ EGG

CALIFORNIA ROLL W/ REAL CRAB, AVOCADO AND CUCUMBER 5 PIECES AND ALSO COMES WITH MISO SOUP 

I ALSO WANTED TO TRY ASAHI BEER IN WHICH I DID IT TASTED GREAT

AFTER ALL NOW THAT I HAVE EATEN AT FUJI FOR THE FIRST TIME THE LUNCH MEAL THAT I HAVE EATEN WASNT THAT BAD AT ALL!!!
author: William B.

description:
Nothing special or memorable... just simple and expensive.  Upon walking into Fuji for lunch today, we were greeted by our Korean waitress Young Jin, quickly seated.  We were somewhat confused about the attitude of the restaurant as there was Mexican music playing.  But what they hey, we were hungry, and didn't want go to far for lunch.  As more folks walked in for lunch, the music quickly changed to Japanese music.  

Prices for lunch weren't insanely unreasonable, but for the quality it definitely wasn't worth it.  We ordered the Vegetable Tempura appetizer which was alright--the batter became quite soggy very fast. But we were hungry, so we didn't take long to kill the plate.  

I ordered the Bento Box of California Roll and Chicken Teriyaki.  Bento's came with miso.  My sister ordered the Oyako Donburi (Chicken/Egg over rice).  The Bento was decent, but definitely nothing special at all.   California Rolls were a good size, but were prepared very sloppy. I guess the sushi chef didn't get a good grip on the bamboo wrap, to where the rice wasn't tightly put together.  Needless to say, the rice came apart very easy.  

The Oyako Don, was lacking in flavor and very bland, Angie had to pour the remaining Tempura sauce over her rice, and even that didn't help much.  

We also ordered the Lion King Roll, which was a California Roll with cooked Salmon on top.  Eh...it was just as sloppily made with the rice falling off on certain parts.  

Overall, the food wasn't terrible, I actually really liked the California Roll and Tempura, but it definitely wasn't anything that made me say "Wow!"

$45.00 with tip...
author: Cass J.

description:
I've been coming here for 9 years. I love this place and bring my family and friends often. Last night was my first time ordering cold sake. Loved it!
My favorite things are Shrimp and vegetable Tempura and seaweed salad. They have a new octopus tempura on the app menu and it's great!
author: DJ C.

description:
Went 18 months later, just as poor a time as last time. Rushed and uninvolved service. Entree brought five minutes before appetizer. Consistency a virtue only where the results are good, had the terrible mussels which were consistent with the terrible mussels I had last time. 

Sashimi wise:  fish was  not fresh and  flaked apart. No flavor. Rice. Not enjoyable.

Very very expensive.very.

Why do Koreans think it is enjoyable to hear them mumble Japanese to entering diners?
author: john d.

description:
I was here for a SUPER DUPER SALTY lunch today.. X_X

Ordered some tea and it never came. I think the waitress just ignored my request or didn't hear me. Get a hearing aid woman!

I had the beef teriyaki with sashimi bento box. The food was good and I got two slivers each of salmon and tuna sashimi. The wasabi tasted like it was fresh out of the tube.

The miso soup was SUPER DUPER SALTY. It was like drinking a liquidated salt cube..ugh..

The last few times was alright, but this place didn't live up to my lunch expectations. 

Enough said about Fuji.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
Their roll with BANANA is amazeballs. Seriously. I know it sounds weird but I've now had it twice and it's so good. Who would have thunk?! Their rolls are very good though I wish they used more of their yummy sauces. 

I'm not a fan of eel and a lot of their rolls have it on/in them. I don't dare ask for a substitution because it usually is an insult to the sushi chef. BUT there are multiple non-eel choices to choose from. 

Service is pretty quick but not incredibly friendly.
author: Erin L.

description:
Having been to fuji at least a few times over the years I have noticed some differences. 

Overall the experience was pretty good and waitresses very attentive to my needs. Aside from that there are a few complaints I have. The cups they use for tea were blistering hot (not standard tea cups), although the high price is expected for a japanese restaurant in the area it doesn't match the quality of their food. Its not very flavorful and is more mediocre in taste. I was anticipating more uniqueness and kept looking for that extra kick that would make me come back for more. This wasn't the case and I think the sushi is lacking.

I probably won't be back anytime soon but it's not because of the establishment.
author: Jade D.

description:
We went here spontaneously and
was impressed by the quick service and presentation of the food, however the fish did not seem to be really fresh. 
We are experienced sushi diners and we felt like the fish could have been a bit better, but it wasn't bad!
Perhaps it was a bad night and the only reason why I give it 3 stars was from the quailty of the fish. The service was great and the atmosphere was fun!
author: EJ G.

description: The best sashimi in San Francisco! Yes I know that's a big call, but it's true. Every couple of weeks we drive to West Portal only to visit Fuji and eat the Sashimi. The side salad has an incredible green dressing. I would buy bottles of it. Great value for money. Staff are not intrusive. If you love Japanese food, you must try this place!
author: Amy M.

description: Incredibly fresh fish. Every bite was breathtaking. I only came for the sushi so I can't speak for the kitchen menu but if it's on par with the sushi I'm sure it's amazing. Definitely coming back and bringing friends.
author: Michael P.

description:
Overpriced, overrated food.  That pretty much sums up my experience here at Fuji in the West Portal area.

I went by myself had the noodle special, which they charged me an extra $2 because it's considered dinner time on a Sunday even though I came during lunch time.  I ordered the seafood ramen with a salmon skin handroll.  The handroll was not too bad, but the seafood ramen was not very good because most everything starting tasting like the shoyu broth that the ramen was in.  Also, it seemed like they just threw a bunch of seafood in it, hoping it would taste good and then the ramen noodles were overcooked that they were basically really soft with no chewiness texture to it.

After I finished that, I noticed the sign that says minimum charge on credit card is $15....I decided to be adventurous and try the toro (marbled tuna) nigiri and the sake (salmon) nigiri.  It was actually my first time ever having toro and after seeing it on cooking shows and whatnot, I was not thoroughly impressed and it cost me $19.50.  The sake was the priciest individual two piece nigiri order I have ever ordered at $5.50.  The taste of it was passable, although I think the slice of the salmon should have been a little thinner, but I guess it was getting my "money's" worth.

Also, the service wasn't that great as there was one struggling waitress trying to managed basically the whole restaurant.  At one point, she cleared away my ramen stuff with my chopsticks after I finished it, and when she gave me my nigiri orders, I basically had to go get the chopsticks myself because she wasn't very conscious of taking my chopsticks away originally.

After tax, tip, and everything, I basically spent $45 on LUNCH.  Now it is partially my fault for being adventurous to try the toro nigiri, but considering everything else, I think this is not my cup of tea.
author: Lawrence E.

description:
Haven't been to this place in many years.  I used to go here to get the live uni.  It was the best I've ever had.  Had a craving for it, so decided to go there.  Since it was a long time ago since I last went there, we decided to call ahead to make sure they still had live uni.  They said they did, so we got there in about 15 minutes.  We placed our order, and then a few minutes later the waitress came back and said they were out.  I was incredulous.  It was 6PM on a Friday.  How could they have run out so quickly?  They said this other table ordered the last one.  I felt like walking out, but we had already placed our initial order for other food.  

When we called, they should have told us that there was only one left.  There was no indication at all that there was any scarcity.  If a customer calls you asking if you have a specific thing and you don't have it when they get there within a reasonable time, that's bad customer service.

When I first had the craving to go there, we were about 40 minutes away.  We detoured specifically to go to Fuji for the uni and were extremely disappointed at their deception.

In terms of actual food we were able to eat, I thought it was just okay.  We had the hamachi sashimi and finding nemo.  I thought both tasted a bit off like they were recently defrosted.  It just doesn't seem right when you bite into hamachi and it breaks apart right away.  To me, it should be a little chewy -- it should kiss you back.
author: Chris W.

description: Food and service was good. Nothing to rave about. Nothing to complain about. Wait.. I really like their salad. Sweet and tangy. MmmMmMmm.
author: Garland W.

description:
Meh! Nothin special. Probably won't go back. We went there for a quick sushi fix tonight. We got a few rolls and an appetizer. Points docked for the appetizer. NOT GOOD! We got the kobe beef carpaccio. Sounds delicious right? right? WRONG! First of all, it was cooked. Wait a minute, isn't carpaccio not cooked? I'm right, right? It tasted like a piece of shabu beef dipped in plain water then wrapped around some cucumbers. It was very beefy, and not in a good way. It also had that weird sour taste, liiiike maybe microwaved meat? I dunno. It wasn't good, that's what I do know. 
The sushi was ok, but iron hand needs to ease up on the eel sauce. The eel sauce drenched the sushi dominating the flavor making it really sweet. Their rolls were mediocre at best. Not going back considering there are much better sushi spots in the area.
author: Janu A.

description: Son and I enjoyed our lunch here. Fresh fish and when the uni is good....we are happy!  Lot's of variety and fast and friendly service.
author: JJAMZ C.

description: I've been eating here for almost 3 years and I can honestly say that I have never had poor service. I go here with my girlfriend every couple of weeks and the one thing which sticks out to me (aside from the excellent service) is the freshness of the sashimi. Also, they have an awesome sake menu!
author: Patrick F.

description:
i grew up around west portal and this place has been here longer than i can remember. in the past 20-something-plus years, i think its changed hands a couple of times... but it has still remained one of our go-to neighborhood places to eat.

so i'm not saying this is the best japanese place in SF.... but in the west portal/sunset/parkside area... i would consider this place one of the better ones.

there's plenty of crazy and fancy rolls... some korean inspired dishes (korean style chirashi or jampong/spicy ramen)... but some solid japanese food and sushi. the fish is always fresh... i love himachi and shiro maguro and it's always good here. i'm a big noodle soupy type of person... and their udon is good too. 

lunch is a great deal... they have ramen noodle specials for $10.50 that come with a big bowl of noodles and a hand roll. bento boxes are HUGE... and the donburis are as well. katsu don is pretty yummy! 

the one dish i have a prob with here though is the sukiyaki! not that its bad... but they use button mushrooms instead of shiitake. completely makes it taste different.... but not bad...but not as it should be.

and i don't know why but i completely enjoy the little side salads here... comes with sunflower seeds. sweet and crunchy! :)
author: Bobbie L.

description:
The food is just "okay". The prices however, are INSANE! 

Two dinner bento boxes and a seaweed side salad for $75 (with NO saki or booze)? Seriously? Wow... I wanted two lunch bento boxes with chicken and tempura. I was told I had to order the (more expensive) dinner versions instead. Fine. I did. When I got home and opened them they were salmon not chicken. So, I called and explained the mixup... To two different people on the staff.... While the server that helped me told me I was at fault. When I asked her why I would order fish from the dinner options after I'd already ordered chicken she just kept repeating I'd ordered a "Number 2" not a "Number 1". The problem is... I DIDN'T ORDER BY NUMBER I ordered by saying "chicken and tempura"...

For almost a hundred dollars without wine, beer, or saki, I don't expect to be called a liar when my order's mixed up. I expect it to be fixed.

I should have known better. They've always been mediocre and overpriced. But, they were close and I decided to splurge. My bad. Never again.
author: Daniel L.

description: Omg! Absolutely amazing food and excellent quality. The waitress(Shannon) is super friendly and helpful to my every sushi needs. I expect high quality food and that is exactly what I experienced here at Fuji. The ambiance is super cozy and friendly. The sushi chefs are very knowledgeable about fish. They answer all my questions about which region the fish is from and even the texture and taste of the fish. Jun and Joseph (the sushi chefs) have me excellent recommendations to particular fish. The Joseph special roll is so freaking tasty, deep fried with hamachi, salmon, and red tuna. Unbelievable. If you want super friendly service, great food, and just a comforting restaurant to eat at, FUJI is the best Japanese I've ever ate at, hands DOWN!
author: Alvin D.

description: This place is incredible.  The costumer service is awesome. Thanks for such a wonderful experience every time I come. The food??? Fresh!!!! This place deserves 2000000 billion stars. I highly recommend this!
author: Kay K.

description: This place has really good sushi. People in SF are too picky sometimes, ive always been pleased here.  Mt fuji roll is fresh
author: Petey F.

description:
I really like this place.  Mostly, I love their selection of special rolls!  While I love nigiri, it is the special rolls that make a sushi place great for me, and Fuji doesn't disappoint.  The waitstaff can usually give a good recommendation on what you might like.

My only problem with this place is how disorganized the seating can be.  There is no place to wait for a table, and it seems like they wait until the last minute to open up the extra tables on the second floor, so it can get a little jammed come dinner time.
author: Terra D.

description: Their fish is really fresh. Had uni nigiri, both with and without shiso, aji, and ikura. I will be coming here again to try their fish listed on their "Daily Catch" board next to the sushi bar.
author: James M.

description: Just moved to the neighborhood. This place has great tasting sushi and can't wait to go back and try more!
author: Jenna P.

description: Apparently, management thinks staffing the entire restaurant with a single waitress is a good plan. No hostess. No one busing the tables. No cashier. Just one poor waitress trying to do it all for a restaurant full of people. Empty tables full of dirty dishes and 10 people waiting to be seated. Just walked out as did 2 others. Imagine we aren't going to be alone. Total fail.
author: Amy B.

description:
really good japanese food from korean people. 
get the sushi combination.  its 7 nigiri pieces followed by sashimi.  i was FULL. from japo food. FULL for $22 bucks. and it was delicious. 

get there early... we went there on friday at 530 and it was packed.
author: Doug ..

description: This is a review purely for lunch specials combined with a complaint about noise. Quite frankly, they're expensive here and no better than Okazu Ya on Taraval. In a few days I've had the same meal at both these places, tempura combo with meat, and the Okazu Ya comes in under $9 while Fuji is $2 more, gave me one shrimp instead of two, and whose salad was not as good. Plus the music was so loud I had to ask them to turn it down: there's absolutely no reason why one should be able to hear every lyric in a song while eating lunch, it's annoying and difficult to talk to friends. What happened to soft Muzak? At least it was inoffensive in its blandness. Now its net based streaming radio of some sort, blasted to the point where I don't know if I'm in a disco or a restaurant. And their choice of music was lousy, I don't really want to hear shrieking R&B in a hopefully quiet Japanese restaurant. And they only turned it down a bit, I could still hear every single lyric. I'll not be back, the expensive food combined with loud music made for an unpleasant dining experience.
author: Rob C.

description: Great little sushi place in San Francisco! I enjoyed the 3 for $12.00 sushi hand rolls. Also the finding nemo roll is too delicious to pass. The only bad thing about this place is the quality of the service. The waiter never came to check up on us and fill our water glasses. Other than that the food was yummy!
author: Andrea M.

description: Great establishment. Really friendly staff. Needs a bigger selection of sushi but the sushi I got was great. The hostess was nice enough to offer to charge my phone when she noticed me fretting over mine dying. I'm new in town and when it dies.... I get lost.
author: Virginia H.

description:
I've past by this place for years and I went for a co-workers birthday dinner. It was a group of about 25 people. We pre-ordered and the food just kept coming and it was fast!

I would recommend that you pre-order if you have a big group because the chefs can prepare and allot enough time to prepare your roll.

It was good and pretty big portions but pretty expensive also. As a group it was pretty expensive but I would say if it was a dinner for two or four the price is about right.

I had the chicken teriyaki and smoked salmon! it was really good...the tomago? egg roll was really sweet also.
author: Brendan L.

description:
Place is pretty good, with innovative though predictably creamy rolls, and fish outside of tuna could stand to be more fresh.

I tried the Dinosaur Foot based on recommendations.  It was so good - but decadent.  *Fried* leaf, with spicy tuna mixed with *creamy* sauce.  

The Godzilla's distinction is based on 1) tempura-fried asparagus 2) sriracha sauce and 3) fried garlic slices 

Double albacore roll is good but last time I had it there was way too much sauce (eel sauce + honey mayo).  I'd get it on the side if you can.  

Our sushi/sashimi platter was sub-par.  The white fish didn't taste so fresh.  Yellowtail, tuna and salmon were great though.  

3 rolls, 1 sashimi/sushi platter + 1 beer cost $67. 

Nice aura.  Run by Koreans.  

I'll be back.
author: Alias A.

description: Loveeeee this place! One of the best sushi restaurant in the neighborhood. Superb presentation and quality. Delicious rolls and sashimi..not to mention their teriyaki chicken and beef are super tender! The staff are super friendly and helpful as well!
author: Karen T.

description: This is my all-time favorite sushi place.  Besides the sushi staples, they have inventive and fun specials.  The thing I go for again and again is their signature "No Problem" roll.  I haven't seen it anywhere else and when visiting another sushi restaurant in town, an ex-employee made me one.   Service is efficient, everything fresh and tasty.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Erika L.

description:
One of my favorite sushi places in the neighborhood.  The many different types of roll are both pleasant to the eyes and tasty to the mouth.  I have only been here for dinner, so I haven't tried their set items on the menu.

For sashimi, they don't stand out.  (I am spoiled by fish market sushi from Hokkaido, Japan).  Others have mention about the price.  Fuji is indeed pricier compared to others; however, I feel the sushi rolls are very consistent and I know I can have a good time in the restaurant.
author: Steven M.

description:
I can't wait to head back for more sushi.  Raw oysters were a bit costly, but great to have on the menu.  Veggy Gyoza was a pleasant surprise...light and flavorful.
Excellent salmon nigiri.  Good combo box deals too.
author: John H.

description: If Lunch special takes forever, don't say that's lunch!! People need to get back to work in 1hr who can't wait at least 45 mins for the " lunch" to be ready!!!
author: Xena P.

description: The food was not as good as I remember. I used to come here all the time. This time the service was awful. It was obvious they wanted us to leave before closing time because they started cleaning up around us.
author: Michelle R.

description:
I've always been in the neighborhood but never went here, even after 7 years in the Bay Area. Finally, got a verbal recommendation and it's true. Real sushi place with big pieces that's fresh.

Found a regular sushi place!
author: Brandon M.

description:
I have been eating at Fuji since I moved to SF and after much sampling of SF Sushi, this place is still one of my favorites.  It is great quality but understated and not overpriced.  

One thing that makes this restaurant stand out to me is that they don't put shrimp in every single roll.  Does anyone else feel like frequent shrimp in sushi (especially tempura) is a scape-goat for freshness???  Not to mention, I am allergic to shrimp so I don't want to feel like a vegetarian trying to find something to eat at a steakhouse when picking my sushi rolls.  

Here are a couple highlights to try:  (1) Dinosaur Foot, soooo good.  I order this every time I come, (2) Finding Nemo - I enjoy my disney creatures thinly sliced ;) 

Those are just two examples but you can't go wrong with any of the sushi.
author: Ryan S.

description:
(Sung to the tune of the theme song to "Cheers")

"Sometimes you wanna go,
      wheeeere nobody knows your naaaaame...
 But they're still glad
      that ya caaaame....
 You want be away from your hood,
      where everyone looks the saaaaame...
 You want to go where nobody knows your naaaaame..."
 (Closing bars....)
 

Ever feel that way?  I do. Dang, sometimes I feel like getting out of my neighborhood and  heading to a nearby spot where NOBODY will know me.  Eat alone. Drink alone. Shut off the cell phone, eliminating any possibility of running into old friends, thereby ensuring that anybody I meet will be someone out of the ordinary.

West Portal is my hood of choice when I'm in this type of funk.  And when I'm in the mood for something to eat, Fuji fits the bill just perfectly.  The 48 Quintara will drop you off 200 yards from the front door, and the L-Taraval will do the same if you get off right when you come out of the tunnel.  Ditto the K and M.

Typical of Japanese places, there's a sushi bar where you can sit by yourself without taking a up a whole table.  Service is prompt, polite, and not terribly verbose.  If you order a beer, they'll always ask you whether you want a big or a small one.  The big one is a bit much for dinner. Unless you plan to sit around for awhile, get the small one (12 oz).  Come the end of dinner, I'll catch the eye of the waitress and make a big "Check" sign in the air.  She'll have it to me in minutes....and it doesn't take long for them to dope out change either.  As an added bonus, all the patrons are generally middle-aged to retired and for the most part pretty reserved. Boisterous, well dressed youngsters off to glamorous events are almost unheard of here.  It's nice....a quiet, subdued clientele adds to the consolation that everyone around you is going to have just as uneventful an evening.

Prices are reasonable too....I usually get three rolls and a Kirin. After the tip, I've still got change from a twenty towards my first round at Portals Tavern down the street.  The rolls I get are...well, rolls.  It's hard to do anything too terribly out of the ordinary with California, Tuna, and Unagi Makis.  I took my friend Tassie here once....she got some outrageously monstrous roll concocted out of a cacophony of stuff.  She's a bit more clued into the Sushi thing, and said it was a lot better than average.

Looking for a quiet place to eat and hang?  I say check it out.  If you see me sitting at the sushi bar relishing my solitude while lost in introspective thought, don't be afraid to say hi.  But if you see me at Portals Tavern an hour later, mention you saw this review and I'll buy you a beer!
author: Mike W.

description: Pleasantly surprised by this place! We've driven by soo many times but never tried them out (which is strange b/c we LOVE Japanese food!). Glad we finally went in and checked it out. Very cozy place, just like a quaint little cafe. Highly recommend their Sushi combo platters as well as the Beef Teriyaki (high quality rib-eye steak). We also had their Sushi Burrito which was yummy but not sure if it was worth $13... Overall, highly recommended! The prices may seem a bit high at first but they serve up quality yummy food and a good ambience, which to me, makes it worth the slightly inflated prices :)
author: Christine S.

description:
You know restaurants that have a great wait staff, and that ONE witchy server just ruins the experience for you? That's what happened to me. Most of the girls there are really sweet, it gets pretty busy, so it's hard to get any attention, but they are still very nice. But this ONE girl, was just rude rude rude. Not just to me, but to everyone. Whatevs. 

Anyway, the food here is really good, on par with most family-ran sushi places. The prices are average too!
author: Tiffany K.

description:
This neighborhood Japanese-american spot is very conveniently located right at a Muni stop on West Portal, and the service is always prompt.

I'm giving it 3 stars because my carnivore friends tell me the sushi is pretty good.  However, from a vegetarian perspective it's not the freshest or healthiest meal in town; there just aren't many options for me here that aren't fried, and the fried options are greasy and heavy.
author: saru k.

description: Fuji is hands down my favorite sushi restaurant that I have ever been to. I am a regular there, I go 1-3 times a week with my boyfriend and they never disappoint. Their salmon sashimi , bagel rolls, double albacore roll, dinosaur foot, oshitashi and hot tea are all my favorites. The fish quality is great, especially the salmon. Not to mention the staff is very friendly. I would definitely recommend.
author: Corinne S.

description:
Best Sushi place in all of San Francisco. It's Korean owned, so make sure not to try and thank them in Japanese if you don't know the difference. 

The rolls are always extremely fresh, and the fish melts in your mouth. They put more fish than rice, which is always nice compared to other places in San Francisco that overload you with too much rice. This place overloads your taste-buds in all the right places! 

The Omega-3 roll is amazing. The toro is delicious. And the prices aren't too hefty. Definitely a must try!
author: Mike S.

description: This is the best sushi I have ever tasted. Butterfly roll, red and white roll, Volcano roll... AMAZEBALLS. Super fresh. Even the salad is good. If i was rich i would eat here everyday, yes EVERYDAY.
author: Ashley B.

description: I came here for dinner this past Sunday night with a friend.  I ordered the sashimi combo, and she ordered the chirashi.  That way we can have a comparison between the two since those are items I usually like to order.  The sashimi set had 12 pieces consisting of three each of tuna, salmon, and yellowtail.  It was pretty standard.  The fish was quite fresh and delicious.  Her chirashi made me envious though because it was highlighted by a large shrimp with the head still there.  It looked like a large amaebi (the sweet shrimp), one of my favorite at some places.  The rest of the chirashi was nicely presented also.  I will definitely order the chirashi next time I go there, and I plan to because the quality seemed quite good.
author: H K.

description: This place is ok.  They have a very extensive menu.  As other yelpers mentioned, the dinosaur foot is the star on the menu - that was awesome.  The shrimp tempura is not that good - not very light or flaky...it was also flat which is strange.  The miso soup is water - don't bother getting it if it's not included with what you order.  The service was pretty good for a casual sushi spot.  I'd imagine their other funky menu items like the dinosaur foot are their standouts, so maybe I'll give it another shot to try some of those.
author: Alyssa A.

description: I have tried sushi a couple of times already, and at very fancy sushi places with disastrous results. I was forced to eat lunch here by some of my Asian friends (I'm white} . They ordered the "finding nemo" sushi (salmon) , and the "mount fuji" sushi (eel). Normally sushi is really gross to me, but this sushi was amazingly delicious. I ate so much. We finish lunch with a red bean ice cream, which I thought was quite unique, but is was also really tasty too. I'm definitely making this a regular lunch place when I'm working in the city. Another thing, the wait staff was really nice too.
author: Mary P.

description: Great food & great atmosphere. We enjoyed our dinner tonight.
author: Gregory F.

description:
I've been to this place more times than I can count over the past few years and this review is much delayed. I've been to many sushi places, in more than one state and even more than one country and this place is still my favorite!!

They have fantastic specialty rolls and honestly that is all I can really comment on. The Godzilla roll, the Lion King, the Mango Roll, the Banana (split?) roll ... I could go on.

They also have wonderfully hot tea, great hot edemame (I'm not a fan of it cold), agadashi tofu, sweet potato sticks and of course they round out your dinner with refreshing slices of oranges!

Parking may not be so hot during the rush hour but if you aim for the neighborhood street west of Portal (Wawona) you may have more luck.
author: J. C.

description: I do like this restaurant . If you're here for good sushi, try some of the special rolls, including Finding Nemo and the 49ers.
author: Ernest L.

description:
Boom. Review #200 for Fuji.

I really like little japanese restaurants like this. One of those places that sits in a sleepy little strip;  you might not notice it unless you were walking right by. But when you do venture through the door, you're surprised to find most seats filled with people happily eating their nigiri and slurping away at the udon. It's popular enough that they have their regulars who sit at the sushi bar on any given night talking to the sushi chefs. The place is very welcoming and spacious. The service was really friendly and attentive, they checked on us consistently and cleared the dishes right away. 

The menu offers a varied selection, while the fresh fish of the day are posted on the wall. They have a lot of different rolls, but one that caught my eye was the Banana Split. I love my bananas and all, but in a sushi roll? 

- I tried the chirashi don, a selection of sashimi spread on a bed of sushi rice. The fish was nice and fresh, and the portions were ample. Not exactly the most adventurous, however, with salmon, yellowtail, tuna, octopus, egg, and mackeral making up the sashimi. There was also a nice, large spotted prawn joining the mix, which made for a nice presentation. The sushi rice was also well cooked. 
- Also tried the crunchy roll, which was spicy tuna covered in tempura crumbs and eel sauce with some more tuna on top. The eel sauce really masks the flavor of anything else in this roll, so we couldn't really taste much of the tuna or spicy tuna. 
- Tempura udon - The broth was fairly light and the noodles were not too chewy. Tempura was ok, as the shrimp tempura seemed a little overcooked and the tempura batter was somewhat dense. They give a pretty good amount of it, though. The udon also has cooked carrots in it. I've heard that's a Korean influence, but I'm not sure. 

Pricewise, I'd say it's slightly above what you would expect to pay at a casual sushi restaurant. $21 for the chirashi don, $4-5 for standard nigiri, $10-15 for big rolls, $14 for tempura udon (that's pricey). Open until 10:30, so if I'm craving sushi, I'll definitely consider coming back to this place.
author: Saunders C.

description:
Went back to Fuji for the first time in months.  We've been addicted to Koo in the Sunset but were looking to mix it up a bit.  While the fish is still good, I don't think I'll be going back there.  They put up signs and pictures everywhere and got rid of a lot of the nigiri.  It's mostly about gringo rolls now.  They were never a really traditional sushi bar in the first place, but now I don't think any Japanese person would recognize what they serve as sushi.  The pieces of fish are cut too big and there's either mayo, tempura, or cream cheese in almost every roll.  

I get them impression that this is what the owners thought they had to do to keep the place in business and by all accounts it's working - there were huge crowds and a party of teenagers going on upstairs.  Still, feels like they made a trade-off somewhere along the way and it's unlikely that Fuji will ever return to their former glory.
author: Melissa Y.

description: Another stop on our West Portal Mothers Day adventure.  As others have mentioned , a tad pricey, about a $1 or 2 above what I usually pay for nigiri sushi.  The service was attentive, creative rolls, I had shiitake maki which I have not seen at other restaurants, it was great.  Delivery of food was a little haphazard, 3 of us had our food while the 4th had to wait.  Sectioned fresh oranges at the end of the meal were a nice touch and a good palate cleanser.  Fish most definitely fresh and one in our party commented they were larger than usual.  A nice, friendly, neighborhood joint. If you are in West Portal, give them a try.
author: Jaci G.

description: Very good to sometimes great. Small place ambiance canned great if you dine later... When it is busy, it is about about the food and usually it is on point.
author: K H.

description: This place has decent sushi.  The servers are cool but that minimum $15 for using your card is kind of annoying.  The vibe is ok inside.  I'd probably roll through here again (no pun intended) but I have a lot of other go-tos on my sushi list so I'm in no rush.
author: Britt B.

description:
Found my new favorite restaurants in West Portal!

Love their rolls, they're pretty creative, and are beautifully presented. Their red and white roll is definitely one of a kind. Salad within a roll? Yummy! I also liked their spicy roll with the chili pepper on top (forgot what it's called).

Overall, great selection of rolls. I went with a party of 6 so we got to try alot of different ones and we were never disappointed.

Only thing is I thought the rolls were a little on the pricey side.
author: Jenny T.

description: Pork Tonkatsu was pretty moist.  The Spicy Tuna roll was okay.  Prices were reasonable.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
I'm craving sushi. I don't want to spend time finding parking. I don't want to drive far. I'm just too lazy to do anything else.

Really only under those circumstances will I go to Fuji. Parking at night here is great, free and plenty of it! It's close by and convenient. I've never had to wait for Fuji, even on a weekend. The food is good and I've never been disappointed, but where this place gets me is the price! I have had both sushi and udon here; both good, but both overpriced.  It's the one of the few Japanese restaurants in the area so it is convenient only if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Diana K.

description:
This is my favorite Sushi Restaurant in all of SF.  The fish is so fresh, the prices are great and the rolls are sooo unique and different.  My favorite is the Mango roll & firecracker.  Both have amazing balances of flavors and ingredients that just pop and melt in your mouth.  Its an experience you need to feel for yourself.  

They also have an amazing dessert.  Fried banana and ice cream.  I usually go with the green tea ice cream since its a bit on the bitter side.  I can go to this place everyday of the week and not get tired.

The only thing I dont like about it is the locations.  Its way out there in the boonies on W Portal.   But well worth the drive.

Love, love love this place.
author: Samantha S.

description:
Decent food but definitely not worth the price. San Francisco has a lot of amazing restaurants and Fuji isn't a stand out restaurant. Good if you can't think of a better place to eat and you are in the area and really want sushi.  

For the money, I would much rather walk down the block to Paradise Pizza and have some amazing food there instead...
author: Mel C.

description:
Went to my good buddy ArtD's birthday party yesterday.  What a fun Japanese Restaurant to eat at.  The server took random orders from us all flying from all directions and got everything on the table except a few Unagi's and Salmon orders didn't make it.

They have lots of napkins and they gave us two complimentary beers as a reward for as all being discreet, old lushes.

It was one of the best get togethers I've been to this year.  Better late in the year than never.

The Nabayeki Udon was different in that it had Salmon in the broth.  I enjoyed it though the noodles seemed slimier than normal.  But I liked it.

The place offers Toro, my favorite order.  It's good but not as good as my favorite sushi places.

Because I had a great time, the food was good, and the service reliable, I'm going to give this 3.5 stars with a liberal bump up to 4 stars.

I'd definitely come here again.
author: Tony U.

description: This is my second time here, their sushi is really fresh and you can get a California roll with real crab and not the imitation stuff.  The rib eye teriyaki was very tender and tasty.  The restaurant was busy but the service was still pretty good.  I'll come here again.
author: Doug W.

description:
I always order Finding Nemo here! Amazing, amazing roll! I don't usually love spicy tuna, but this over here, is an exception! Then I love the Lion King roll! My friend from Seattle asked me to bring her one Lion King roll when I visited her. Yep, that's how much she loves it. and she lives in Seattle! LOL. 
Other than that, the sushi and sashimi is pretty fresh too! Too bad they are kind of in the expensive side of my budget.
author: Miss C.

description:
Found this place by accident. My friend and I were looking for a Japanese restaurant and we happened to be in West Portal. This corner restaurant caught our eye and fortunately, there was parking down the block. Don't get me wrong though, finding parking here is just as hard as any other damned San Francisco street. It's all based on luck.

Anyway, onto the food. The first time we came there on a Friday night, we had to wait about 15 minutes for a table. We ended up being seated at the bar in front of all the sushi action. The chefs nonchalantly drink their beer while slicing, dicing and rolling, btw. "MMoshi Moshi!!!" Oh sorry, got a lil carried away. Ahem.

They have a fairly good menu with a decent variety, from special rolls to the standard bento box, for those who are in the mood for, well, a standard taste. The rainbow roll ended up being one of our faves. Check out the photo I submitted. Presentation, cleanliness and a very friendly, attentive, kimono wearing wait staff are all great here. Do call for reservations to get seated ASAP. The only thing that I wish could be improved about this place is the size. Tables are very close together.
author: Michelle G.

description:
Fuji Sushi is the best!
1.) Finding Nemo Roll: The most amazing roll I have ever had in my ENTIRE life, yeah you better believe it. Spicy tuna roll topped with avacado and salmon drizzled with eel sauce...yummm
2.) Lion King Roll: Delicious! Even though it is cooked fish.
3.) Firecracker: If you want something spicy this is the roll for you!
4.) Double Albacore: Yummy too!
author: Annika K.

description: Fuji is surprising, mainly because their specialty rolls feel like culinary achievements in and of themselves.  Their Dinosaur Foot seems like a prehistoric jungle of things that crunch and ooze, but the restaurant doesn't always execute simple dishes nearly as well.  At Fuji, you're coming for the crazy bells and whistles, and patrons who just want some tuna or unagi might feel like this place is a bit hit-or-miss.
author: Michael D.
