description:
I love fish, but not raw.  So this review is strictly for their cooked items.

When I come here it's always for the Tempura Udon.  YUMM......

[Forrest Gump Voice]  That's all I have to say about that.
author: Duckie A.

description:
Fugi has been my favorite sushi spot for the past 8 years. The fish is very fresh, the rolls are very tasty, and the service is excellent. I'm actually surprised by a few of the mediocre reviews. In eight years I have never had a bad experience here. 

Metered street parking on West Portal, but if its busy, you can usually find non-metered street parking a block away.
author: Kelly E.

description: Honestly I'm so mad about the delivery guy, I haven't even tried it but I'm taking 2 stars away.  EVERY other restaurant I order from has option to add tip on the card and I didn't realize there wasn't one.  Being that I only had $1 in my wallet I gave it to him an apologized saying I didn't see an option to tip online when I ordered.  the guy stood in my gate and argued with me saying he lives on tips and was I kidding what's he supposed to do with $1, seriously I don't care tips are not required they are a thank you plus I usually only tip a couple bucks for delivery (that's why I pay for delivery fee)  Never ordering from here ever again worst service ever.  I felt bad about not tipping much now I think the guy was just a jerk.  I was standing in my doorway like what am I supposed to do I don't have any other cash on me...ahhhh jeez
author: Nirea S.

description:
I placed an order to go on the phone, when I went to pick it up I was ignored by every employee that walked by me for at least 5  minutes. I had to ask for help.

Bad service leaves a bad taste in my mouth just like the chicken teriyaki did.

I will not return.
author: Dee D.

description:
I have to share this story, I really do. 

So since I was a party of one and the sushi bar was completely empty, the hostess sat me at the sushi bar. Based on the "vibe" I was not feeling the sushi experience, so I decided to order from the menu. 

While waiting for my dinner combo to show, here sits an elderly "white" couple just a few seats down from me. 

Chef: Would you like to order Sushi? 
Lady: No, I don't like fish, especially raw fish. 
Bob: Looks around, ummm, ya, I am sitting at a Sushi bar 
Chef: How about a California Roll? 
Lady: What is that? 
Chef: Explains......with imitation Crab. 
Lady: Imitation Crab, can you make it with real crab? I don't do imitation anything.
Bob: Looks around, oh yeah, I am not in Los Angeles.
Chef: Of course......precedes to craft a CA roll. 
Lady: Oh, wait, I don't like rice. 
Bob: Looks around again, ummm, ya, this is a Japanese restaurant. 
Chef: Ummm, we can make it with a cucumber Skin. 
Lady: Great, I will try that. 
Lady: Wow, I love Sushi !
Bob: Shakes head

For me, I ordered the dinner combination (A) because I was slightly concerned about the quality of the fish and for some bizarre reason, the palate of the patrons. 

I will get right to the point, frankly, nothing was notable about the meal and the miso soup tasted a bit odd to me. 

For the price, I think you can find a better value elsewhere.
author: Bob S.

description: Don't go there! Their sushi was horrible and price was so expensive! I order their Donburi to give a try however I was so disappointed the egg was over cook vegetables were not fresh! Service was really bad, me and my boy friend have been waiting over 20 mins to took our order! Sucks ever !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Evonne T.

description:
I always try to support business in my neighborhood and I must say I was not impressed with the food nor the atmosphere.
The vibe on West Portal has changed; the crowd is younger and expect a bit more finesse in the food.  Sure we go to some of the old coffee shops for breakfast, lunch, brunch etc. but at dinner, I expect more.
The wait staff seemed overwhelmed, but they were courteous.  They had to open the upstairs dining room, however the stairs were crowded with high chairs and left over dining chairs.  We were promptly seated and the waitress took our drink order promptly and then took our meal order.
The table was sticky as if it had just been wiped with a wet cloth w/out much attention to the cleanliness. 
Food looked like it had been plated in a rather casual manner w/out visual appeal.
The decor needs a make over, old and tired;  blotchy walls where there may have been a water leak and just painted over.
Don't get me wrong, I love dive places, but there wasn't a japanese person eating there and that says something.  I always go where I see the people from the country who's cuisine eating.
author: don b.

description:
Best fresh sushi as sushi goes and I have many years of experience of leaving in Japan.  Also a lot of very authentic starters and Japanese dishes.

But watch your wallet, special orders of sushi can be astronomically expensive (toro at $19.50).  They also routinely make mistakes on the check.

Service can be very poor as soon as the room fills up (waitresses seem exhausted) except at the bar where you always get special attention.

Also refuse to go upstairs the room is cramped,low ceiling, very hot and humid, old looking and a little dirty and they forget about serving you....
author: Space K.

description: This is one of the best sushi places i have yet to find in the city.  It's so cute and it's a few blocks away from the West Portal muni station.  Their sushi is scrumptious and it's price is very decent.  It's well worth the money and experience coming here.
author: Janice V.

description:
Never again... 

This was one of the places I used to go pretty frequently. Not the best environment, nor friendly and welcoming atmosphere, but overall it was OK because of the food quality. Lately I realized that the prices started going up every time I went there. But I was still OK with it as long as it wasn't too pricey. 

We went there tonight with my wife. Again, the prices seemed higher than last time I was there ($7 for 2pcs Unagi, $7.5 for 3 pieces of oysters etc). But I wanted to treat my wife so we ordered quite a bit of food. As I always do in any Japanese restaurant, I asked for extra ginger because I just love it. But when I saw the check I was annoyed: they charged $2 for the ginger. I am never ever charged for extra ginger in any Japanese restaurant. I complained to the waitress but they didn't care. Not even an explanation.

Yes, $2 is not a big amount, especially considering I paid over $100 for both my wife and myself. But as a matter of principle, I will never go to this restaurant again. The fact that they charged me this amount where it is free everywhere else drew the line for me (even green tea is complimentary in most Japanese restaurants but not in here). 

They lost a good customer because of their $2-pathetic-greediness.
author: Mike O.

description:
Either yelpers these days don't know what good food is, or they are just lying through their teeth. 

I've been coming to Fuji for years, with both family and friends. And I must say I have yet to be disappointed. I feel bad for those who had a bad experience here because quite frankly I never had. 

The service, to my taste, is what good normal service should be. The staff are nice, friendly and attentive. Nothing bad, nothing over the top special. Though it can get slow during the busy hours but c'mon what restaurant won't be bogged down by a slew of hungry customers? 

The food is always delicious. The sushi is always fresh. From the salmon sashimi and spicy tuna, to even the uni, it is all fresh. Their tempura is hot, and not too greasy. And their teriyaki chicken is superb. Unlike some other restaurants that serve distasteful burned chicken drenched in teriyaki sauce, Fuji's is light and not overpowering.

It is run by koreans, but who cares, cause the food is good. Its hard to find a decent, consistent Japanese restaurant anyway. Fuji is my go to place for Japanese. Yes, it may be a bit pricy but hey, it is the west portal area, rent is high. For those of you who have had a bad day here, I urge you to try it again. To the new folks, when you get a chance, come out here and try it. I hope you won't be disappointed.

~ Fuji is delicate.
author: Brian L.

description: I give this place 5 stars because it has my favorite roll in the city.....the Liger. If you like salmon, unagi, tempura, and all the fixings in one bite, look no further, favorite roll in SF. Favorite Japanese restaurant outside S.F, gotta go to Mikuni in and around Sacramento/Roseville, Ca.
author: Ignace P.

description:
I used to love this restaurant until I had a TERRIBLE experience tonight.  I will never go back.  My parents drove 8 hours from southern California into town to see my husband and I for our anniversary.  We wanted to take them somewhere we liked and Fuji was one of our favorites.  Unfortunately, tonight was so bad that I am writing my first Yelp review ever just to vent.

First, my husband just had knee surgery and I have a 19 month old little girl.  This did not stop the hostess from seating her friends who walked in way after us ahead of everyone who was waiting.  Then when I saw seats open at the bar after 30 minutes of waiting and asked if we could sit there I was told that the people she was going to seat there were outside smoking.  I told her I had a baby that needed to go to bed, parents that drove 8 hours and a husband that just had knee surgery.  I said if they were outside smoking maybe she should seat us first since they were taking their time.  She actually made a face at me and walked away with no further communication. 

When we finally got a seat, this same woman was unfortunately our waitress.  She did not even come to our table for 30 minutes.  She then came and took our order and brought back all the wrong drinks.  We couldn't even tell her because when we tried to she walked away. WE DIDN'T SEE HER AGAIN FOR ANOTHER HALF HOUR.  We sat there for an entire hour with a couple of the wrong drinks, no chopsticks and no food.  We repeatedly saw people who came in after us receive their food in a timely manner, eat and leave.  By this time it was my daughter's bed time and she was very upset.

After an hour of waiting with hardly any service at all, they brought out one roll.  The waitress walked away as we tried to tell her we didn't have chopsticks. We went to get them ourselves and she proceeded to glare, role her eyes and give a nasty look to us.  We asked for our food to be boxed up because my daughter was so upset we had to leave.  When we got our bill, we were charged full price for our drinks, and it was half price sake night.  We finally spoke to the manager on the phone and he took 30% off of our meal.  Unfortunately, when we got home HALF OF OUR FOOD WASN'T EVEN IN THE TO-GO BOXES.  By this point we were completely exasperated and decided it was simply the WORST dining experience of our lives.

Point in case:  we won't EVER be going back.  There are too many wonderful food experiences in San Francisco to waste your time here. I would recommend this to my worst enemy,
author: Justine K.

description:
Went here a few weeks ago and I came in just before the evening rush.  It  seemed as though they were short staffed.  The main sushi chef actually gave us our plates of food.  The sushi took a bit long to come out, and it was okay.  

I must say the service was really slow.  I'm hoping it was an off day.  No one came to refill our tea through out our whole meal.  We were missing one of our rolls, and I can see the waitress and chef trying to figure out which table the roll belonged too.  When we finally got the roll, she said it took the kitchen awhile to make it, but I saw it sitting on the counter for at least 20 minutes.  

I doubt I'll go back.
author: Allie D.

description: Used to come here more often and enjoyed their sushi, lately the results have been inconsistent, good then bad...etc. Came in recently on a Wednesday night. Sushi rice was not seasoned and fish was not fresh and was stringy. We aren't even big sushi snobs. Really disappointed considering they are one a few sushi joints in our neighborhood. Tired of the crap shoot and spending a decent amount of money for really bland sushi. Ugh.
author: Judy H.

description:
If there was a lower rating possible, I would have given it to Fuji Sushi! 

We had a horrible experience there.  Ordered two Toro maguro, and got very bad fish.  It was very hard to chew and had a bad after taste.  Bad fish to start with, and probably was sitting in the fridge too long.

 My husband and I told the waitress about it.  She has a grin on her face, and disappeared.  When she came back a few minutes later, she told us that they are not able to take it back.  We were very surprised, and asked to speak with the owner.

He is a very arrogant Korean man, and I am SO surprised he is still in business.  He came back saying that he will not return the tuna.  We told him that we go to his restaurant every week, and we are very good customers.  I explained to him that this is bad fish, and it should not be served.  He snapped back saying that 'HE DOES NOT CARE"!!  Can you believe an owner saying that to his customer???

Well, I am sure never going back there again.  Be careful about your choice, there are a lot of amazing sushi restaurants and SF, do not choose Fuji!!!
author: Maria H.

description:
Whenever I want sushi, (often) this is the first place I think of. And, whenever I want to take someone out for sushi... this is the first place I think of. 

I'm a little biased since it's pretty close by to where I live, but I've always gotten good service, it's not too expensive, and the people I've taken have liked and recommended it to others. 

Plus, I am a big fan of their vegetable sushi dinner.
author: Theresa F.

description:
First off, half off all sake and beer on THURSDAYS!!!  That was a pleasant surprise when I went there =)

They have absolutely the freshest sashimi I've ever tasted.  I ordered the assorted sashimi plate and it was DIVINE.  Buttery and fatty salmon, tuna, and hamachi.  A-MAZ-ING.

The party I was with also ordered shrimp tempura (nice and crispy!), beef sukjyaki, a mango roll, AAANNND a large bottle of sake called Otokayama (16% alcohol people!  and tasty!).  It was a heavenly meal.  

I love going here b/c it's a neighborhood place that isn't super crowded in the early afternoon.  The service there is fine, and the sunshine always makes its way through the big windows.  This place is good for dates without making things too fancy, and there's always amazing fresh sushi.
author: Marissa N.

description:
On yet another drug rep lunch dime we ate here. I have to report I was shocked to find such decent sushi after my abysmal experiences at Kamakura and the dearth of good West Portal restaurants in general.  You really get your money's worth here.   The Fuji Sushi Assortment came with so many pieces of sushi I could finish it.  Historically I think that is a first for me!  I usually clean my plate and those of surrounding diners when I have sushi.  It was only $22!  SUPER DEAL! Well actually it didn't cost me a dime so SUPER AWESOME FANTASTIC DEAL! The one thing I didn't care for was their agedashi tofu appetizer but if you are going to screw up something in a Japanese restaurant I'm glad it's the tofu and not the fish.
I would definitely hit these guys up again...even if it was on my own dime.
author: Jill D.

description: Good Food...very fresh and consistent.  However, a bit overpriced and they don't have sushi happy hour?! If they added sushi happy hour, I would be there more than twice per week.  Much too expensive for what you get.
author: Katie D.

description: This is my absolute favorite sushi spot. The Liger roll is GREAT! Fantastic service and excellent rolls. Food it good and the service is consistent.
author: M A.

description:
Food was delicious but overpriced...but yelping because it was the worst service I've ever received!
Walked in 2 pm on a Sunday, family of 8 eating, and two other couples, 4 uncleared tables and thewaitress said sorry, there wasnt a seat!  (she later turned away a group of 8 rahter than take one minute to clear 2 adjacent tables and put themtogether!
Party of 8 just turned away because of snotty, lazy waitress!)

We were shown to a table by the bussed dishes and asked for the one by the window, she almost fainted.  She was so rude, we were afraid to ask for water, never got napkins, nothing.  I realized she must not be Japanese as no Japanese woman would ever be this rude...sure enough, she said she wasn't.

Unbelievable any owner would tolerate rude, lazy, bitchy waitress, but now having read the other reviews about the boss, I'm not surprised.  Sad because the food was good...but would not only never go back, would actively encourage others not to.
author: andrea m.

description:
I usually come here for a lunch special every once in a while. While I'm used to a lot of "Chinese" sushi places, this place is a bit more multicultural.

One of the hostess/servers? is Mongolian, and I believe the sushi chef is Korean. Japanese or chinese servers as well, and a Mexican/Latin back staff. cool.

I like the food that I've had there, actually, I dont think I've ever had a big gripe about the food. The fish could have been fresher, but the standards aren't any higher at most standard sushi restaurants, and atleast it isnt substandard compared to other "typical" sushi restaurants. 

I like this place, the staff, the food, the prices, the area... it's found it's way into my rotation. 

Check their hours before going for a late lunch .. they close in the afternoon before dinner service.
author: Tyrone B.

description:
Location was great with plenty of Parking (evening time)

Alot of White people LOL

Service was OK

Food was good

need to go there one more time before giving my final rating
author: Kenneth C.

description:
Went to Fuji for their lunch special. Wanted to order the Tekka Maki + 5 nigiri but one of them was shrimp and I am allergic. Requested a substitution with something non-shellfish, probably cheaper for them than the shrimp, but the only way they were willing to do this was to charge me extra (the waiter didn't know how much, and didn't even know how much the special originally was). 

My partner got the fish katsu, and it tasted as if they had trusted the Gorton's fisherman a little too much. Salad was iceberg lettuce and it also came with miso and rice. All this for $10. 

We agree with other reviewers that Taraval Okazu Ya has better quality, service, and value.
author: Michael G.

description:
Leave it to WP to have the most Main Street sushi joint in town.  Like Taraval Okazu Ya, only less crowded.  Like Jimisan, only less...red.  It's not as awesome (or even as cheap) as Sangha, but it's a convenient alternative for when I'm not feeling as trendy.  

The sushi breakdown:

Double Albacore -- I don't see what all the fuss is about.  Plus, it falls apart.
Looking For Mango -- Now we're talking. Shiny, slippery, sublime.
Dinosaur Foot -- Looks gimmicky at first, but as we all know, in a sushi joint that's frequently a good thing, and one bite confirms this as a classic.
author: Wes M.

description:
Last time I ate here, I watched some old lady complain about not being able to eat her sushi. I figured that was some old-lady bitching so that didn't really bother me. What bothered me was watching the chef grab the old-lady-gummed sushi with his hand, toss it in the trash and then go back to preparing someone else's meal...

That made me sad because I liked coming here, but I won't come again. Damn.
author: Tom S.

description: This place shares the same name as one of my friend which is why I first went in. And boy was it good. I had nigiri. The chefs are definitely skilled since the consistency of the nigiri was really good. And the pieces were bite size and wasn't any hassle to eat. Definitely going back
author: Raun D.

description:
This could just be me, but when I go out to dinner with other yelpers, I wonder if they too are crafting their reviews in their head as we dine.  Oh, it's just me?  And I'm a big loser?  No matter, because my reviews will go down in the annals of history as some of the best reviews ever written, and it is all because I'm a big dork who tries to form sentences (not related to the conversation at hand) in her head while eating dinner with 3 other fabulous yelpers.

Moving on...

In order to get our cerebral neurons properly firing before trivia night, Ali Gator, Jessica L, Angelo, and I decided to come here and plan our strategy.  Although I'm not gaga over sushi, as I don't eat anything from the ocean that has a face, I am learning to enjoy other food at these sort of establishments, such as gyoza and cucumber rolls.  I'm also deathly allergic to shellfish, which tends to complicate matters.

Waitress comes over, we order drinks.  When I change my order from a small hot sake to a large hot sake- she says "3 Sapporos."  This statement did not instill confidence in me for the remainder of the evening, but I gave her the benefit of the doubt.  It was a Tuesday night, after all.  After a wait that was wholly unnecessary, we order our food.  I order beef gyoza.  I ask her if they pan fry it, and if not, could they cook it in an oil that hasn't been used by other fried items- sometimes shellfish residuals from tempura stays in the oil.  Nope, they can't do that, sorry.  I'm kind of a rebel, so I took my chances and ordered it anyway.  I only got a little throat itch, so no big deal.  I also ordered chicken/vegetables on a skewer with teryaki sauce, a kappa maki roll, and one of them omelette rolls.  I also asked for a glass of water.  I suppose I should start eating fish, because they did have some pretty pictures in their little book, but I just couldn't do it.  I'll let my companions explain what they ordered, as I've probably bored the reader to tears already at this point.

Moving on...

So they bring my gyoza (and I managed not to die), my kappa maki rolls and my omelette roll things.  They forgot my chicken skewer thing.  Gyoza was good, but my rolls were...not.  Granted, 99% of my sushi experience has been at Coach Sushi, so I might be a little biased because Coach and I are TIGHT, but the rolls were meh.  They were small, not that good, and fell apart, which basically topped off a mediocre experience.

Eh.
author: Pam S.

description:
Had the Tendon here for lunch today. It was KILLER! The Donburi is just like "Grandma used to make". Totally country style. Comfort food at it's best. Also had the Agadashi Tofu and it was only "meh". Wouldn't get it again, so minus one star. Japanese owned and operated which in my book is totally key. Jammin' the JPop over the sound system didn't hurt either. Don't frequent West Portal to often, but it seems like a pretty good spot. Parking was a breeze at lunchtime. 

Domo!
author: Natas N.

description:
If I had written this review a year ago, I would have given it five stars without any hesitation. I have frequented this restaurant since it first opened years ago, almost weekly for lunch. Unfortunately, the chef that used to run the place left a few months ago, and an unfortunate but subsequent downgrading of their food has happened.

It may be that I am a very picky person, or it may be that Fuji used to be an excellent, excellent place which raised my standards, but there was a period of time when their nigiri did not taste fresh, which is very distasteful to me, especially when it comes to raw fish. I could not finish my meal, and I almost decided to never go back. Only its lasting legacy from the past brought me back again.

Luckily, I have recently been there for dinner many times and their chirashi sushi (sashimi sushi served arranged over sushi rice) has not been problematic at all. So it appears that whatever issue it was with their raw fish has been resolved.

I also really like their salad dressing, which is not the cream kind that is often served in sushi restaurants, but rather a light, house-made vinegarette. 

Service has always been superb, and, while dinner can be expensive, the restaurant's lunch specials are very affordable, and quite moderately priced. The place is also well-kept and neat.

My only current complaint is that Fuji used to serve the best beef teriyaki in town. It was not over-cooked, or too tough. Since the change of chefs, I have been hard-pressed to find something comparable. 

Although Fuji has lost its flare that made it exceptional for me, I would still go there just because it is still an average to good sushi restaurant with good service and tasteful food in general. However, if I ever figure out where that chef went, I will take all my business there.
author: Diana Y.

description:
I suppose one day I will want some Fuji and it won't be there. will I love it then ? reflect. I've always had good meals here but since I am with a man who has the appetite of a bulimic T-rex, we choose eateries that serve plates piled high with grub. my fav dish is chicken katsu with a caterpillar roll (boyfriend eats more than half of my plate so I am starving by the end of the evening. great fun). Fuji is more enjoyable when I'm with people who have normal appetites.

really cool: the last time I was here, an incredibly hot Japanese gangster type was at the sushi bar. I swear he looked like Ken Watanabe's twin bro. delicious.
author: Prima D.

description:
On my first visit here we rolled 11 deep and the staff took care of us with no problems whatsoever! They even hooked us up with a few complimentary large beers (we dropped some serious coin for dinner), which was unexpected and a nice touch...

We ordered all kinds of food and drinks (alcoholic and non-alcoholic) and nothing was forgotten...of course, the staff had nothing to do with the instance when one of my friends' orders was eaten by another friend, but that's another story... :-)

They seated us in the upstairs room and went to the trouble to set up and aim three fans at our table, just in case we were getting too hot battling over the tasty pieces of sushi that were being delivered to our table.

The items that stood out most for me were the unagi (warm and tender), sashimi (loved the salmon) and a specialty roll that was not on the regular menu. The spicy tuna I ordered was also tasty...

Overall the staff was very friendly and accommodating, the food was great and the prices were fair. Definitely a place that I'll get back to, especially since it's close to my 'hood!
author: Art D.

description: The staff is super friendly and I have loved everything I have ever ordered there. The sushi is very decent, not the all time greatest I have had but never disappoints. I have been here 5 times now. The Hawaiian Poki, Double Albacore, Hole in One, Finding Nemo. Great sushi in West Portal for sure.
author: Michael S.

description:
fish appeared fresh....bit icy cold...but decent....."large hot sake..please~!".....the minuscule portions wasn't going to do justice fillin' this hungry tummy.....drink the hunger away~!.....the "special" rolls were....well....sorry...but the rolls were one of the sloppiest...again...miuscule.....while the 4 pieces of seasoned tuna tartar over tempura fried leaf was creative...the taste came mostly from the thick heavy saucing of teriyaki and 1000 island type mixture...not impressed

for service...the waitresses.....so sweet and nice....soft spoken.....i feel bad even asking for water......interior is decently clean for a sushi joint in this aged building......

sashimi and rolls lunch for two with drinks and nice buzz?....$60......
author: Hen A.

description:
On the ninth day of Christmas, 
My true love sent to me
Nine Dragons a-rolling,
Eight shoes a-kicking,  http://www.yelp.com/biz/8lneqGA0ixALuirgRtZbTw?hrid=fNGW5NAkeDZMHc1Km54nFA
Seven kids a-skipping,  http://www.yelp.com/biz/FuBTcEUbnFcpUq611r4yVA?hrid=Ycf9-eD_N-uNNxHyHgE06w
Six lights a-blinking,  http://www.yelp.com/biz/AqlNaZ4K47-TK-BJXyyHPw?hrid=WfFbkExfDAiy0GlSse8zzA
Five flower moments,  http://www.yelp.com/biz/6GMGLY2q03EAzsjLBu1u-Q?hrid=j2Y_Q_5We1BhKjPGCAMDDQ
Four ballet dancers,  http://www.yelp.com/biz/sU1Wt3c7TB3DvHsnwaDtJw?hrid=cOQwqCORVHmwubOsUWWlKg
Three PPQ dishes,  http://www.yelp.com/biz/9QXEJdRizwCYBjGX_go_Qw?hrid=uc52Uh6AM9Epe4pF24EC3w
Two Red Devil bands,  http://www.yelp.com/biz/BapzmqIvIth6bwCdFP047Q?hrid=KsZMEA6fPqfQNC3n4XmfQA
And a ticket for a Century movie!  http://www.yelp.com/biz/lRyFL9ujt0GMwTvwRY2JHw?hrid=rEKb2nwguqQLn_5Wa39-Dg


Fuji is a clean, spacious and friendly restaurant on a more quiet section of West Portal. A greeting from the chef behind the sushi bar is a nice touch. Good service. The noise level is low, and you can really focus in on your dinner conversation. Park a block away and you can avoid the parking meters. If you're on a date, it would be a pleasant walk to the Empire theater for an artsy film.

I've tried Fuji a few times, and I group it with Yo Yo's in the Mission District. Both these restaurants are okay, and quiet my hunger, but they serve unremarkable sushi. I don't expect to thoroughly enjoy my meals at these restaurants, and I've yet to be convinced different. When I asked the waitress about sushi recommendations at Fuji, she pointed at mostly the $12.95 range. The prices may be inflated because St. Francis Woods is nearby, but that's some serious change for mediocre sushi. For Asian food on West Portal, I'd go the extra block to Hahn's BBQ for a more tasty meal.
author: Teddy B.

description:
Pretty good for a sushi place. I liked in the worst part of sf, but luckily this little west portal neighborhood was nearby. 

-piping hot tea (perfect for COOLD sf weather)--but they charge for tea.
-when it says spicy (with that little sign), it is ACTUALLY spicy
-GREEN TEA CHEESCAKE!! kind of like green tea ice cream... you don't quite know how to describe HOW it tastes like green tea, but it does =)

-1 for the service. took forever to bring the spicy flakes for the udon and to refill our tea. fyi it's a korean run japanese restaurant for anyone with purist biases.
author: Joyce D.

description:
10/4/06 Just went with my best friend from high school and my roommate. It's all about the rolls. For ex., the big foot, is a deep friend shinzo leaf with an incredibly generous spicy tuna mixature that makes eating with your hands sexy. 

We just had dinner here by chance, because we were driving back and happened to passing through West Portal and hankering for sushi. We eye'd 3 or our options on the West Portal strip and something about the feng shui of this place just struck us as the real deal. The nigiri was incredibly tasty and the rolls on the special were so clever but not pushing the fusion button. Real sushi rolls that were incredible. How some people would jones for a burrito from (fill in your favorite taqueria) is how I feel about their Mango  roll!
author: Jean W.

description:
I am going to maintain my perspective while I write this review.

You see, I have an apartment within walking distance of Tsukiji, the world's largest fish auction house located in Tokyo. I spend about half my time in Tokyo and while there, hit up one of the surrounding, 24 hour sushi joints at least one a week. I'm completely spoiled when it comes to fresh fish and great sushi, and I realize that.

Still, what lowered my rating of this place were things completely within the scope of their control. Of the nigiri we had last night, the kanpachi and the uni were actually quite fresh, slightly exceeding my expectation. And the roll was really creative and delicious (tempura shrimp, spicy maguro, avacado, with a thin, fish-like slab of mango on top - "American sushi" but what the hell, it tasted good). 

What ruined the experience of the nigiri for me was that the rice was hard, under vinegared, and worst of all...cold.  simply no excuse for that.

I realize this is a family restaurant is the focus is on much more than sushi, so perhaps staying with the katsu, gyoza, and other dishes mentioned here will keep you satisfied. But when it comes to sushi, don't get your hopes up too high.
author: Peter T.

description:
As the cute little Leprechaun on the Food Network (30 Minute Meals) would say for the food here..and I quote "Yumm..OH".  

The food here is fantabulous.. Especially the Korean Chirashi!! It's a big bowl of steaming hot sushi rice with fresh sashimi, apple slices, green onions, and watercress to garnish. It also comes with a spicy red sauce so you can mix it all together (Think Bi Bim Bop). Remember to ask for minced garlic and jalapenos on the side. They won't bring it to you unless you ask for it! I know the ingredients sounds odd and you might think that the added jalapenos in addition to the spicy sauce would burn your booty-hole.. But it is well worth the sensation! (Ya know, if it does burn)

But you're taking it from a girl who packs a bottle of hot sauce in her purse, everywhere she goes.. 
Now what's in the flask is another story.

The torro (fatty tuna) sashimi is also one of the best I've tried.. It melts like buttah!
author: H To The W.

description: Sake and Asahi are a must. The miso is good, the sushi is good too. The service is great too. I accidentally left my scarf there and they held it there for over a week until I could finally retrieve it.
author: Krista M.

description:
Freshest, best, most creative sushi in the area.  We go here just about every Sunday for dinner.  Dinosaur foot and Godzilla roll are two specials that you shouldn't miss (plus they're fun to say).  Even their non-sushi/sashimi items are good, like their udon, tempura, gyoza and edamame.  Service is pretty good too.  Really not too much to complain about except maybe when we sit upstairs and the service is a tad bit slower.  But then again, if you're in a rush, just insist on a downstairs table.

Oh, just thought of one bad point.  The tables along the wall on the main floor can feel cramped if you have more than one person sitting on either side of the table.  Especially cramped if you're really sensitive about having your personal space.
author: spiff e.

description:
Glamor!  Style!  Swanky setting!  Award winning wine list!

Well, you won't get any of that here at Fuji.  But, what you will get is really good sushi with friendly, attentive service.

We actually started with the beef gyoza since I was super hungry.  They were light, crispy and delicious.  

The smoked salmon nigiri was amazing.  They gave us a nice thick cut of yummy, flavorful fish.  The kampachi nigiri was good too but was overshadowed by the smoked salmon.

The Tanzania roll was really tasty although I don't understand why a sushi place names a roll for an African nation.   The Finding Nemo and Double Hamachi were also excellent.

I made the mistake of ordering a glass of Sauvignon Blanc.  Really bad & very sweet.  Skip the wine and just enjoy the fish.
author: Jeff P.

description: So tasty and beautiful presentation. Looking forward to getting my next Mango roll.
author: Link A.

description: First off service here is horrible. Its slow, and they make you feel like you are inconveniencing them by asking them for a glass of water or something they should have already given you. The waitresses are all sitting around by the sushi bar while you try to get their attention for 10 minutes. Sushi is okay, certainly not the best and definitetly over priced, and this review is coming from a person who has eaten sushi all over the city. Miso soup, nasty, and nothing in it! Seriously? Overall would never come here again.
author: Alyssa O.

description: Wow, what a variance of opinion on this restaurant. Count me on the negative side. Fuji is again one of those non-traditional Japanese restaurants - run by non Japanese people. So I'm not expecting much, something comparable to Taraval Okazuya or Noreiga Teriyaki in the Sunset. In other words, I just want some decent edible fish . If I was looking for great fish, gotta go to a REAL Japanese sushi bar and spend the big bucks (not gonna divulge my bar of choice, sorry.) Fuji is just so darn expensive for average, and the entire dining experience is just unpleasant. I mean seating is cramped, and heaven forbid you get stuck upstairs, where it is hot with no circulation and the servers only check on you once a year. Tried several times to make sure, and confirmed not I won't be back.
author: Dom L.

description: LOVE, LOVE, LOVE. Excellent food, wonderful service. I grew up eating Japanese food in Hawaii and this place is wonderful. They are very careful about their sushi preparation and do an excellent job. The menu is pretty extensive, delicious, and the Asahi beer on tap is unbelievable! Recommend Highly.
author: Jennifer W.

description: After a disappointing meal at Bushido the night before.  We had to go to Fuji for decent food and decent service.  We sort of got it.  They forgot one of our orders, but it's okay. It was 10x better than Bushido.
author: Carrie-C N.

description:
Consistently great Japanese food and friendly service, can't ask for more.

The menu is fairly extensive menu and covers teriyaki, katsu and tempura well. The freshness of the fish took me by surprise and I was very happy with my Chef's selection of sushi.

They even serve red bean icecream!
author: Kristi K.

description:
Familiarity, I'd like you to meet my friend, Contempt.

We've been going to Fuji on a regular basis for the past year or so, and I must say I think I've just gotten plain worn out on the place.  It's not that anything is bad, per se, it's just that nothing is particularly outstanding either.  

As others note, this is the best sushi place in the neighborhood.  But frankly, this should be seen more as an incentive to choose another neighborhood for sushi than an endorsement for Fuji.  

The positive spin on the atmosphere here would be to label it down to earth.  The negative way of spinning it would be a little funky and distinctly cluttered, with a variety of tacky adornments on the walls and window sills, a restaurant in need of a what-not shelf.  Woe betide you should you hit Fuji on a busy night and get seated upstairs, the road less traveled when it comes to waitstaff.

Service is hit and miss, and sometimes a meal here can be extremely pleasant, other times not so pleasant.  From personal observation, if not experience, the people at the bar look to be having a way better time than other patrons, and perhaps that's where I'm going next before saying goodbye permanently.
author: Hugh B.

description: This is a great traditional Japanese restaurant with great food and excellent service.  The hospitality is what you would expect from a traditional Japanese restaurant.  Food is always fresh and tasty.  Prices are moderate and the wait is usually only 15 minutes during busy times.  Highly recommend this place if you are looking for great Japanese food and sushi.
author: Mark L.

description:
Wow! 

The best sushi in town!  Just tell Tom the sushi chef give me what "Boris" gets and you will be satisfied beyond belief.

Double Albacore was in my dreams, mixed in with my Tuna Mango morsels...will go back again, again, and again now that we know Fuji exists!

And really, Tom is very personable that I think we made a new friend- that's good service when the chef says goodbye knowing our names and giving us a pound- great experience.



BTW: you may ask- who is "Boris"?  He's one bad ass ruski who drives the 2nd fastest Porsche in the world and damn that man knows his sushi!  And of course I can't leave out S & S for taking us there and sharing the "Boris" experience with us. We got some real friends =)
author: J S.

description:
Starting to offer more creative rolls.  

Still kinda pricier than other places, but I like to think that I'm worth it.  So I still treat myself here if I don't want to drive far for sushi.
author: Denise B.

description: It is a really nice place. GREAT sushi and teriyaki combos. The green tea cheesecake is not so good, but everything else I tried is really fresh and yummy
author: Emilia Z.

description:
I ended up here pretty randomly.  I went to a film festival at sf state that night and after traveling on the M muni line found myself in a weird place called West Portal.  West Portal doesn't feel like it is exactly part of the city.  I felt like I really traveled far away. 

This restaurant is cozy and that night the windows were fogged up and the place had christmas lights up.  The food was tasty but the service seemed really slow albeit friendly.
author: Lauren S.

description:
(3.5 stars)

Is it possible that the Lion King roll here is the best thing that's ever happened to me?  Probably.  I know other places have the same roll, but I haven't given them the honor of trying their versions yet.

All their other stuff?  Good.  Not spectacular, but good.

I like this place.  Yeah, it's a pricier than some of the low-end sushi joints (see: Sushi Suki across the street), but you get what you pay for.  The food is better quality, and the service is probably better.  The kimonos the waitresses wear are pretty too--which counts for something :)
author: Sarah T.

description:
It's all about the special rolls when you come to Fuji.  Of course, their tempura, teriyaki dishes, and other non-sushi lunch and dinner items are good too.  They just don't exactly stand out to me.  The special rolls are something else...  a lot of them are completely original combinations so what you eat is different than what you can get at other sushi restaurants.  The double albacore is one of my favorites, but that's just one example of many.  

Definitely your best bet for Japanese if you live in the area.  If not, the special rolls are well worth the trip to West Portal.  Come with a small group and have everybody choose a different roll to share.  Consume.  Order a couple more.
author: Jen P.

description:
The rolls and menu are pretty basic, but the fish is usually fresh, and they are cheap!

I have never had to wait, the staff is so friendly, and food is out quick.
author: Alex F.

description:
when you've had really good sushi, nothing can really top it.  After Oyaji, I found Fuji really lacking.  Their toro was good, but not as good.  Their ocean trout is good, and again, not as good.  

There are a lot of rolls and it's quite inventive, w/ some names like Linger Roll and Finding Nemo roll, but they all taste only ok.  

Minus 1 star for the way too salty soy sauce.  For some reasons, probably the brand that they use, it is super salty.  Covers the flavor of the fish.  Also, the wasabi is not spicy at all.  You can't taste anything.  

Why I gave 2 stars was b/c the service was really great.  They refilled our tea so many times and they introduce the rolls that we're having, which is pretty nice.
author: AhLin C.

description:
I came here with a couple of buddies since we just wanted to walk down from his house to West Portal for dinner. We didn't really find anything we liked, so we just kept walking until we reached Fuji.

It's  pretty small place. The food was decent. I ordered the salmon sashimi dinner plate. It came with miso soup and a bowl of salad, as well as a bowl of rice. I was starving so I thought it was good. It was a bit on the pricey side, and I've had better salmon sashimi, but it was better than what I was expecting.
author: Martin L.

description: Half price sake and beer on Thursdays.  A-mazing
author: Carter G.

description:
what can i say about fuji?  obviously, with four stars, i liked it.  it's a small restaurant nestled on a street corner in west portal.  although small, it wasn't cramped...very cozy and welcoming.  the wait staff are attentive, yet far from overwhelming.  we had dinner here on a thursday night, and took advantage of 1/2 off sake & beer!

the food:  we had sake sashimi, looking for mango roll, red dragon roll, and i believe the finding nemo roll.  they were all good, and generously sized rolls.  we also had a couple of large hot sakes and asahis...aside from my sashimi fix, this is primarily what i came here for...especially after a rare hectic work day =P

upon closing time, we left as full, buzzed and happy patrons =)
author: Ian Q.

description:
It had been a couple years since I had been to Fuji, back when I got  good sized groups of sushi fans to eat there on a few occasions.  Earlier tonight, my wife and I waited just a few minutes for perfect seats at the center of the sushi bar, right in front of the head sushi chef.  For a Friday night, the place was understandably busy.  We could see most of the other food going to other customers were a variety of maki rolls and other entrees.  Our interest was pure and simple:  nigiri, and lots of it!

The meal was surprisingly sublime.  The fish was cool, tender, fresh, and properly seasoned as appropriate, while the rice was perfectly room temperature, with the right balance of chewiness, smoothness, and subtle vinegar flavor.  We believe we were at an advantage with our close proximity to the head sushi chef.  The time from him making the nigiri to it entering our mouths could literally be measured in seconds.

Our favorites were the anago, the bonito, and the escolar, all bursting with flavor and wonderful mouth feel.  They were so good, we doubled up on those orders.  

Also good were the hotate, the kampachi, and the toro.  Less impressive, but still good, was the saba.  The hamachi sashimi was very nice.  The sunomono was good as well - I enjoyed the fresh piece of taco (octopus) from it.

The chef did comp us a special piece of toro with a nori wrap, no rice, and some sort of light color salty sauce.  That was quite nice of him.

For comparison, my wife and I commented to each other that this nigiri meal easily beat recent similar meals at Kabuto and Nagano on Geary St., and Higuma in Redwood City.  While not cheap, it was well worth the cost.

Perhaps our experience would not have been as good if we had not sat at the sushi bar, nor focused on nigiri, but since we thoroughly enjoyed this one meal, and I've had good experiences before at Fuji, I'm assigning a 5 star rating.  Choose wisely at this place for a great meal.
author: Mason W.

description: I've been coming here for a few years with my boyfriend and we both like it. The fish is fresh, the portions are good and we always leave full. It's close, convenient, and the servers and sushi chefs are all really nice and friendly. It is a tad expensive though. They also have a good selection of sake!
author: Jacquelyn M.

description:
I live in the neighborhood and it's really hard to find a good asian restaurant in this neighborhood let alone find an authentic japanese restaurant in the entire city.   I go to this restaurant out of mere convenience and laziness to drive.  The food here is very ordinary and the sushi is not consistent so beware.  I believe they finally got a filter for their water because it didn't taste like the pipe however their miso soup does have that pipe taste.  

Another note is to stay away from fried foods because the oil is not consistently fresh.  I gave it 3 stars because of the convenience and very attentive service.
author: Oscar F.

description: Horrible service and food! For paying $160, I usually pay at least 18% tips but Joseph deserved $4. Don't ever go there! Unless you want to eat corpse. We went there at 2 and they made us order from dinner menu. Fish is not fresh and I had a stomachache after eating there.
author: Fiona L.

description:
The food was good, prices fair and atmosphere fine.  What set Fuji apart for me was some of the rolls.

My wife and I shared the Volcano roll (which included tempura shrimp, spicy tuna, cucumber, spicy sauce, tobiko and I don't recall what else).  It was nicely spicy.  We also shared the Finding Nemo roll, a fairly basic (but quite good) salmon and avocado roll.

The moment I saw the Banana Split roll on the menu I had to order it.  Tempura shrimp, cucumber, spicy crabmeat, and avocado wrapped in slices of banana and topped with eel sauce and tempura crumbs.  It was incredibly unique and worked pretty well.  It wasn't amazing, but I would definitely order it frequently.  The banana was actually just about perfect, fragrant and ripe, but not over ripe.

Only two small negatives - but they are really small. We ordered the tempura shrimp for my 3 year old - which comes with the miso soup.  There were only 3 or 4 small cubes of tofu in the soup, wish there'd been more.  Also, my son didn't really care for any of the tempura veggies that came with the shrimp, but carrot and potato are probably the only ones he would like.
author: Greg H.

description: Had the salmon teriyaki lunch special.  The mainly iceberg salad was warm with a watery dressing that had absolutely no taste.  There was water at the bottom of the bowl.  The rice was hard/dry and room temperature.  The salmon was simply bad and from the way it felt in my mouth it seemed like it was cooked, or rather OVERcooked, way before (like even days before) I ordered it and then it was reheated, but just ever so slightly!  The teriyaki sauce was insipid.  Be warned.  Just because the plates are 15" in diameter doesn't make the food taste any better.
author: Rona M.

description: Rather second class Japanese cuisine, I think. This city does offer some better quality Japanese restaurants, so it is hard to know why people would put up with the sort of short cuts in cooking that this restaurant seems to take. A sukiyaki tasted of canned sauce, old vegetables and was close to inedible. Even the rice seemed carelessly cooked, undercooked. The restaurant itself looks old, worn, in the style of cheap corner cafe.  On the brighter side, a sushi dish was quite nice, if not remarkable. If you are out for Japanese food, look further as there are much better opportunities.
author: J M.

description: The service is horrible.  If you're coming here for sushi, the rolls are actually 4 stars worth though a little on the pricey side but we waited 30 freakin minutes for a roll that they claimed takes a long time to create make even though we knew damn well that they didn't put our order in.  Everyone was standin in there playin around and it was hard to get anyone's attention since they were all talkin to each other or looking down balancing receipts.  Though the food wasn't bad, I wouldn't come back here so I don't have to deal with their lies and bullshit.  Ok for take-out if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Emily L.

description: Started with the spicy tuna roll.  So fresh, and so spicy!  Then we had dinner boxes, which came with salad (really good vinaigrette with sunflower seeds) and miso soup.  Chicken teriyaki was so tender, and the salmon teriyaki wasn't over-cooked. tuna and salmon sashimi was really nice, tempura was really crisp on the outside.  Service was good. Will definitely be coming here again. Next time we'll try more sushi.  Only downside...we had to listen to Mariah Carey's Xmas album three times in a row before someone changed the CD.
author: Miriam G.

description:
Kick ass sushi in a quiet packed little place.
Its the most creative sushi you'll find at a good price.
author: Bullet H.

description: This place serves the most fresh and amazing sushi my favorite one is called the firecracker. The service is good, I thank my sister everytime I eat there for turning me on to it.
author: nadia p.

description:
This is a place that I stop to eat nearly EVERY time I go to San Francisco, which is usually a few times a year. Great Sushi! Love the Liger! 

Seating can be cramped during rush hours of the restaurant, and it is a little pricey. Beyond that, it is fabulous.
author: Catherine A.

description: I've been here twice and I have to say that this is a great sushi place. I ordered the Fuji sushi assortment the first time and then the Chef's Choice sushi dish the second time. Both were very good and had  a nice variety of fish; which was very fresh and melted in my mouth when I ate it. The portions are pretty good too. I know sushi dishes can be kind of small but these pieces were big and i felt full after finishing my dish. The dinner and lunch boxes my friends ordered also had nice portions. It's a little pricey but it's worth the money. Recommended if you're looking for japanese food around west portal!
author: Austin C.

description: I scream sushi, you scream sushi, we all scream sushi. And going to Fuji makes you scream for more. They offer delicious sashimi and nigiri that is extremely fresh and a great cut of fish. Their rolls are inventive and have awesome flavor. Their Red & White Roll, Double Albacore Roll, and Scallop Roll are some of the standouts. Don't miss the gyoza, yakitori and shrimp tempura appetizers. Fuji's a great find in West Portal. Also they have a mezzanine level where you can have a huge group if you'd like.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
Fresh Sushi. Great selection of special rolls. Service lacked a little, but we were at the sushi bar... so I wasn't xpecting too much attention on a busy night. 

Paired with a good movie up the street, this is an excellent date night sushi spot. I will definitely be returning.
author: Lawrence A.

description:
Don't think the owner/manager knows what he's doing here. And he stands there at the end of the sushi bar watching/staring at everyone. It's kind of uncomfortable, like he's making sure you like it/ don't have complaints.
Well, I have one. Try using FRESH fish in a Japanese sushi restaurant, cheapo! I mean c'mon, who are you trying to fool? No wonder the place is half empty on a Friday night. My brother's first complaint was that the sashimi salad he'd ordered was supposed have 8 pieces of maguro- he got 5 and the waitress told him that's how the dish is NOW- not like it is in the menu. Hmmm.
Have had better pre-made sushi at Paradise Market in Marin. DO NOT order any roe nigiri, unless you want to get sick eating old, pre-packed, unfresh fish eggs. GAMIEST Aji (Spanish Mackeral) I've ever had- and it was on the fresh/special list. Yikes! Wild salmom nigiri was not that fresh or tasty either. Hamachi was decent- but do you need a HUGE piece of fish laying over a tiny ball of rice?? I don't mean to complain, but the presentation is off from the get go when this happens, right?
Too bad. Nice staff, good location, fairly brisk service. Pretty bad sushi.
author: Sean E.

description:
I've changed my mind about Fuji sushi.  I didn't used to think it was super special, but I've really found some rolls that I just love.  

The Godzilla.  I don't know why but this one is so good to me.  It's tempura asparagus wrapped in red tuna with a spicy ponzu sauce on it.  It's definitely different and very tasty.  The service is also always pretty good.  

Overall, 4 stars!
author: Kali H.

description: Really fresh sashimi!  Tried this place for first time last night.  Was really impressed with the amazingly fresh yellowtail sashimi and the magura tuna was good too.  Didn't care for the california roll--although made with fresh crab, it was dry...and the yakitori chicken was on the dry side too.  Will definitely go back for the sashimis.
author: Kailee Q.

description:
We tried this place on a recommendation from a friend. I was disappointed. The only good item we had was the dinosaur foot. I'm sticking with Sushi Bistro- it's waaaay better. Maybe I should keep that to myself though because it's been pretty packed there lately.
*************************************************************************
Update: 7/16/2008. Had the dinosaur foot...LOVED it. The double albacore roll...ikura with quail egg...spicy tuna roll, hamachi, tuna, salmon...all exceptional. Fuji is really great. They even put toasted rice in my tea when I requested it. It takes the edge off. I love this place. Thanks for reintroducing me to Fuji Miss Michelle. Muah!
author: Sherie R.

description:
Good, reliable japanese food; they seem to do a better job on the sushi, but i haven't had anything bad here.  The usual array of selections along with a few unusual rolls.  The service is lowkey and friendly, although it can be a bit slow when the place gets busy.  The prices are, I think,  pretty typical for a japanese restaurant like this; we're usually around $50 or so for two with a nice selection of food.

Basically, a good place if you're in the neighborhood and craving some japanese food!
author: John R.

description: I've been going here for years and this place never disappoints.  Mind you I've only eaten sushi here and never had any cooked food.  Lots of creative rolls and the sauces they put on them are unreal.  Try the Dinosaur Foot.
author: D D.

description:
Food: Delicious! I love coming here. Recently came here for lunch and had the chicken teriyaki. Lunch and dinner portions are huge. You get soup, salad, and rice. The adashi tofu is also good.

Price: Not bad at all. About $8 a person for lunch and $12 for dinner

Location: Located in West Portal on a corner. Parking available at meters or side streets

Service: Very speedy and friendly.

Atmosphere: Nice and relaxing. I enjoyed the Disney music that was playing in the background last time I was there!
author: Miss H K.

description:
The sushi was fresh, rolls were ok and that sums up the food. For the price that we paid I've had better. The service was very good, the waitress couldn't stop smiling the whole night.

The unagi was over cooked, but the uni was good.
author: Sun-Kai P.

description:
This place ain't cheap, and we all know I like cheap. But I like this place, too.

We got a whole bunch of rolls, figuring that usually there are like 6 or so pieces in each roll.  Most of the rolls we got seemed much bigger... maybe 10 pieces or so. They were also around $12 each.

There was one that looked like a salad with sushi and that was good. Be warned it's a bit spicy too.  Since my fiancee orders for us, I couldn't actually tell you what it was. But it was good.

The waitresses were nice.  They should have told us we were ordering too much, though. Or maybe we look like piggies.

I brought one of the rolls to work for lunch since we couldn't finish them all over dinner. I can't wait to eat it.

5 stars because it's well worth coming back to for quality sushi rolls.
author: Robert L.

description:
I've been going to Fuji for so long.  I love this place.  They have very good sushi as well as good service.  The staff is very friendly and is always welcoming.  
  It would be nice if there were more choices on West Portal for Japanese, but this is the best they got.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Hate Sushi, Love Fuji.

I have never understood paying 10$ for a skinny piece of fish over rice. But at Fuji, get the real goodness.

Looking 4 Mango, Una Tem and Double Albacore.

Double Albacore is your more traditional sushi. Two kinds of fish over a roll of rice with avacado and some other specialities.

Mango is well mango. It's very ingenious, a piece of mango over fish, over that rice thing.

Then Una Tem, the best. The otherside is soft with a little eel, avacado or something and then inside is crunchy because of carrots and some other goodies. The change in complexion makes for a sweet finish.

highly Recommended, a bit pricey.
author: Joe Z.

description: Ummm one of my Favorite sushi spots! Each time I go I fall in love all over. Awesome food, great staff, always an awesome time! Go and try it for yourself too! I think Wednesday or Thursday they have a deal on Sake to yummm!
author: Jena L.

description:
I love this place. I always order sashimi dinner combination. It comes with miso soup, salad, and rice.

The fish is fresh. We've tried other sushi places, but we always come back to Fuji.

Try Stuff Mushroom. It's super yummy!!!
author: Sweet J.

description: Everything here delicious. I have never been disappointed with the food. Be careful if you go on a Thursday night; it's super crowded, but the staff is very nice.
author: Sabrina S.

description: Ok, so I've been to this restaurant dozens of times, and I will probably continue to go, but when the sushi chef is messing around with his cell phone, and then man-handling my food without washing his hands, it's pretty gross, not to mention a health code violation. The rolls are tasty, but recently have been made pretty sloppily. Still looking for the best sushi in SF.
author: Princess D.

description:
My husband introduced me to the wonderful world of Japenese food through Fuji's which has become our absolute favorite restaurant. We ate there in celebration the night we found out we were expecting our first baby (due in 5 weeks!) and have dined there pretty much every Sunday night since. The staff are all really friendly and helpful and not pushy or too chatty. They know us well by now and a few have even made a point of asking us if we'll bring our baby in once it's born so they can meet "it." :-) It's really nice to eat at such a friendly place.

Being a non-sushi eater right now, I LOVE the California rolls (better than many other places I've tried). The spinach oshidashi is a pregnant woman's dream - healthy (iron) and salty (it's spinach with a sesame, soy and vinegar dressing). If you like chicken, the yakitori skewers are wonderful. The salmon teriyaki is some of the best I've tried - and the dinner portion is very generous. 

Some people may not like Fuji's because it's not an edgy sushi joint, but it's excellent food, decent prices and a really nice, quiet atmosphere. Definitely worth a try.
author: Laura G.

description:
After a long day of yelping its always nice to find a solid place to eat!

This place is right on the corner and has a nice atmosphere. Its staffed by real Japanese people (no suprise really) that take their job seriously (aka they do do it well). Typical 10-12 dollar special roll prices, and 4.50 nigiri. Some people say thats expensive, but its right on for sushi if you ask me. 2 people, 3 special rolls + 2pcs nigiri = just under $45 total sounds good to me.

Anyway, we got the mushroom & hamachi roll (forgot the name), Finding Nemo, the mango roll (forgot name, top left of menu), and Hamachi nigiri (which i use to test out all new sushi joints). All the rolls where interesting, with a variety of flavors that make them not quite your typical fare. Sometimes this works out great, like the mushrrom & hamachi roll, but for the mango roll it ends up being one of those things that interesting to try, but probably not something you'd go back for.

The Hamachi (yellow-tail) nigiri was RIDICULOUSLY good :) I try this at every sushi place, and so far Fuji ranks up there at the top of all the non-top-dollar-sushi-joints,

All in all, this is now my #1 desitnation for Sushi. Its super easy to get to since its in the West Portal shopping area, and the price is right for some good eats!
author: Josh S.

description: Decent sushi place. I like the neighborhood. We had a bunch of rolls...one was like all mushroom, one was topped with mango slices. They had some unique rolls here but like all sushi places, it's pricey. It's a good date place.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Overpriced, substandard Japanese food.

They charge way too much for the poor quality.  It's an embarassment to charge regular Japanese restaurant prices for what they serve.  There is no way a Japanese person would ever step foot into this place because it's just not worth the price, nor are the dishes anything close to authentic.  

As a local who grew up in this area it's an embarassment. Please don't believe the hype from the reviews written by their employees or insiders.

I challenge anyone to go here an try the sukiyaki and you will immediately understand what I am talking about. I understand that there are very few alternatives in walking distance.  (A short drive would be to check out K's Kitchen or Sushi Shoh instead)

But really why pay full fare for sub-par food? 

And really?  Not a good sign when their Food Safety Inspection score hovers in the 70s for years...oh now below 70. Criminal to run a sushi joint with such a low health safety score...

22-Oct-2014       Inspection Type: Routine - Unscheduled           Score: 69

You can find restaurant inspection scores at SF dept of health sfdph.org
author: Yohdaddy M.

description:
I accidentally came across this restaurant while strolling in the westportal area. The chef at the sushi bar has lots of energy and makes it a fun place to go and sit at the bar. But the most important thing- sushi rolls were great.

they also have sushi dishes with unique names. I think one of them had a cute name related to mangoes or something. I will try it next time ifor sure though.
author: Sunil P.

description:
Hmm lessee...what was the phrase from the girlfriend again?  Oh yes...

"That place was so disgusting I wouldn't feed it to our dog!  Who puts mustard on sushi?"

She ordered two rolls, I've been on a shashimi kick so I ordered that.  I'm 75% done with my very mediocre fish (had to ask myself "OK what day is it...should they have gotten a fresh delivery recently or are they coming off a weekend? Nope, they really should have fish fresher than what I get at the j-town supermarket") and she's still sitting there looking at her tea.  Finally I grumble at the wait staff, they wander off to look at what they had written on the bill - did you completely forget the order you took already?  There were 4 other tables left, the bar was mostly quiet.  I know, this is what I get for sitting at a table and not at the bar.

I too used to come to this place a few years ago(call it 2000 or so) and it was much better then.  I think it's turned into a place funded by the geriatrics who wander down out of St. Francis Wood, not knowing any better.

When we left, there was still shiro maguro sashimi left on my plate, and not because I was full.  This experience (shiro maguro sashimi dinner, maguro sashimi, one roll for her(second was canceled) set me back $50.)  I guess I helped fund their existence a little, too.

They get two stars only because I love raw fish, and I didn't get sick.  

Oh and PS, the dog did eat the roll.
author: John K.

description:
so my friends say the food is normal, but you know what? I have considered buying stock in Fuji or just buying the restaurant outright because it would be cheaper than continuing to eat there for the rest of my life. We have gone about a gazillion times I'd say, about. And it's really cute because they already know what we are going to order. They never complain about our numerous special requests, and always friendly, and have good yummy food. it's a chill space run by a family. 
and most importantly, they have fried banana fingers with green tea ice cream. and it's so good, I think about it all the time. 
thanks for the great times, Fuji. 
good place for groups.
author: Jess P.

description:
This has become my new sushi spot in SF.  I'm shocked that some people have beef with the prices.  If someone could show me a better, cheaper sushi place anywhere in the city I would probably lobby my boss to let me work out of the restaurant.
 The larger $12 rolls have all been delicious, but the Finding Nemo and the Double Albacore stick out.  There is also a roll with spinach that I always order, and although I love the idea of eating oysters, I've never HONESTLY enjoyed them, until Fuji.  The add just a touch of spice (Cayenne I believe) that makes all the difference in the world to me.
  I have only been let down when I'm at a fancy sushi restaurant and pay $25+ for a roll, it's because places like Fuji are just as tasty and much more reasonable.
author: Fritz J.

description: I've been here several times, mostly for the convenience of easy parking, and the food has been consistently pretty good...BUT I can't say the same for the service. We showed up when they were really busy, and as an former professional waitress, I understand how crazy things get, but you HAVE to greet your tables. Pretending you don't see new tables when you're busy doesn't mean that they're not there. Not a good customer service technique at all...
author: Brielle N.

description:
i don't believe that rolls are a true representation of what japanese cuisine has to offer.  japanese cuisine (to me) is supposed to be modest, simple and reflect the purity of the food item that you are about to consume (sashimi, broiled mackeral, etc.) 

however, with the explosion of westernized influences on japanese cuisine, rolls are extremely popular in the US.  and to me, if it's made right, it can be a fantastic explosion of flavors and textures that our palatte can take on at once.

i believe that of all the west portal sushi establishments, this place does it right.  on a thursday nght, all of the tables were packed.  service can be a bit slow, but i barely noticed it since i was partaking in their thursday night special of 1/2 off sake and beer (and i'm a big sucker for discounted drinks).

the liger roll came and it was extremely well presented.  the honey and wasabi mayo combo on plate is such a fabulous contrast!  the portions were filling and the fish was fresh.  the saba donburi is pretty on point as well.  they serve the mackeral on a huge white platter, and while you may think that it's odd to serve it on a huge plate, i appreciated it because it allowed the mackeral to stand on it's own and shine, rather than drown in a sea of red in the typical bento boxes.

a bit expensive for sushi, but it's a welcome and comforting change from the party-filled atmosphere at other establishments in the neighborhood.  great place to go if you've got kids or want to have a conversation with someone without yelling at the top of your lungs.  and remember, you can't drink if you damage your vocal cords!
author: Lucy W.

description: I have a tendency to only write reviews for things that  are very exceptional or very disappointing.  Fuji is exceptional.  My first visit was for a quick lunch. I'm not a fan of sushi, but I do love teriyaki & tempura.  I got a lunch combo. The shrimp & veggie tempura was super tasty: crispy without being greasy, served piping hot, and with huge vegetables (good portion size).   The beef teriyaki was extremely tender, cut into perfect strips, cooked to perfection with a delicious sauce.  And the best part, not a bit of fat/gristle on the meat. Oh, and the salad was tasty too.  I am so often disappointed by the quality of meat used in teriyaki, but not here. They use high quality meats & vegetables.  I went back a second time before writing a review and was equally pleased.  It's now my regular lunch spot. The service is pretty good too. Perhaps a bit slow, but worth it.
author: Sherri H.

description:
My family's experience at this restaurant was not  good. 
Food was just okay. Nothing was extraordinary that would make us want to go back.  Service was slow. The owner had no PR at all, a bit arrogant in fact.

There are better sushi places to go where you can get good food and great service. This place was a big disappointment!!!
author: Maritel A.

description: I went here for the first time 6:30 PM.  Half empty yet with three waitresses walking around and NOT seeming to noticed we had closed our menus and were trying to get someone's attention.  I thought $18.00 for mediocre chicken Teri and a bowl of rice a bit on the high side.  The bento box at $20.00 wasn't much to write home about.  Too much money for too little flavor and service.   I wouldn't return.
author: Adriann D.

description:
What a disappointment.  Service is okay but the food is NOT WORTH THE PRICE. 

I'm sorry but this place is much too overpriced for the quality of the food.  Unlike an authentic Sushi restaurant this place is another knock off where they cut corners but charge high prices for mediocre food.  The patrons are mostly locals (not Asian) which tells you that they are not discriminating about real Japanese food.

Take for example the sukiyaki - it was vegetables braised in brown water.  It was a disgrace.  The miso was salty.  The rice in the sushi was aweful.

The sushi chefs were putting their beer glasses on the sushi counter.... faux pas if this were Japan.

I would never take a Japanese person to this place.
Sorry but you should drive down the penninsula for better sushi.
Or get a better value at Tani's kitchen in Westlake.
author: yohs m.

description:
I used to "like" Fuji....When I say "like", I mean it was o.k., not great, but passable.  I'd go there when I was in the mood for suhsi, but not in the mood for driving.  My latest visit made me realize that bad sushi is alot more painful than driving any day of the week.

I didn't get sick or anything, but the sushi was unremarkable.  In fact, my toro sashimi was still frozen when served to us.  The escolar was pretty tasty, but the way they cut it made it look pretty unappetizing.   I don't think I'll be coming back here for a while.
author: Richard K.

description:
I love this place! They have creative rolls that are to die for! (Personal Faves: Banana Split, Looking for Mango, Firecracker) I'd say this is definitely my favorite sushi spot in the city that I've found. Service is usually pretty good but I took away 1 star because last time I was there I think the waitress forgot about us completely and we waited 45 minutes for our food!... That is unusal for Fuji and normally we don't wait too long at all. 

I will say that this is not a good spot to sake bomb unless you reserve the room upstairs. It's a little too quiet of a spot to get all that crazy and when my friends and I tried sakebombing there we got some stink-eyes from other patrons.
author: Kelly R.

description: This restaurant's food and service overall are pretty good, but I find it appalling that they serve bluefin tuna, which is an endangered species. There are other species of tuna that are significantly less overfished, and there is no need to hunt the remaining bluefins into extinction. As consumers we need to pressure restaurants like this to do the right thing and serve only sustainable seafood. I will avoid Fuji as long as they serve bluefin tuna.
author: Jeff P.

description: Fuji always serve the freshest fish. The freshness is just too sweet to pass. It is true that the size of the plate is moderate for the prize but its big enough to fill me up. I haven't tried to eat dinner at Fuji, but they get crowded too on lunchtime, usually. Servers were pretty nice, and never miss the time to quickly respond.
author: Sean M.

description: I am not the biggest fan of fancy sushi rolls but this place turned out to be the exception for me.  One of my friends is a regular here so she knew exactly what to order. We had the Beef Tataki for the appetizer, Godzilla roll, dinosaur foot and I asked for the tuna roll because I was afraid I wouldn't like the giant rolls. Each dish came out really fast and tasted fresh. The sushi had just the right amount of sauce and wasn't over done with lots of junk on it. We finished our meal with fried bananas with mango and green tea ice cream. I finally found a sushi place where I can enjoy the fancy creations, too bad it is in San Francisco and I live in Southern California.
author: Vicki G.

description: Went in on a Saturday with my boyfriend. It was very quiet and uncomfortable. No music and no one else in the restaurant. We reluctantly sat down and looked over the drink menu. The sake selections are hot or cold. Really? How can you be a serious Sushi restaurant and that is your sake selection? So I looked over the wine list, also terrible. Ok on to the food. Overpriced, not fresh, and not what we had in mind at all. With so few options in the area for Sushi it would be nice if this place would fix these things.
author: Heather M.

description: The Big Roll Sushi section had a lot of interesting options, and I had high hopes for a shrimp, cucumber and lettuce concoction called the Boston Roll. Unfortunately the friendly service and nice interior could not make up for each small piece coming with less than one shrimp, a shred of cucumber and a sliver of lettuce. Disappointing.
author: Jason B.

description:
the sushi options are limited around west portal but don't waste your money here.

we came here for lunch. we had some rolls and soups - basic, just ok, not great. 

the lamest thing we saw was a sign that they were charging for tea because of a "water shortage." if you want to charge for tea, that's fine. but be honest about it. don't make up lame excuses.
author: huong n.

description: I love sushi but I have to admit that the price sometimes keeps me away.  Aside from Fuji being in the neighborhood the menus is extensive and the prices are really reasonable.  I've always had really fresh fish and the tempura is good too.  Sometimes I take the easy route and order one of the combo plates to-go.
author: Jessica G.

description: This is a classic sushi and Japanese food place. The sushi is very high quality and very fresh.  They have a moderate amount of variety and creativity.  They are good for lunch and dinner.  My bill always ends up bigger than expected.  But that is always the case when you get sushi!
author: john h.

description: If I ever eat specialty rolls, this would be the only spot. They are good I must say. Try their Dinosaur Foot. Three stars for inconsistent service and lack of communications. Some of the girls are afraid of customers or at least telling them how long would the wait be.
author: Brock L.

description: This is where my brother and I introduced our parents to sushi!  My dad LOVED it.  It was a fun experience.  The service was really super fast (because it was almost closing time) but we really didn't mind because we were starving.  The food was all very tasty and fresh.  The rolls were well prepared and interesting enough...nothing too crazy for the parents.  I'd go back for sure.  It was very reasonably priced which makes it a place you'd want to come back frequently.
author: Kirun M.

description: The people here are very nice and welcoming.  However, the sushi is not all that great.  The escolar was pretty fishy and I wasn't all that impressed by the hamachi, which was a little off in color.
author: Jason S.

description: arrived at 615 on a friday night and it was packed!  food was delicious and of good quality.  ordered chicken sukiyaki, a variety of rolls (there were many to choose from!) , asashi tofu, and baked hamachi dished.  we enjoyed them all.  prices were reasonable.  we'd definitely return and arrive no later than 630p on a friday night especially we need to park in west portal!
author: FoodJunkie S.

description: I've been eating here for almost two years. It was one of the first sushi places I went to in the city and I continue to go there once a month or so. This rivals my other top favorite, Sushi Bistro. The fish quality is great, the rice is firm and moist, the seaweed falls apart as it should (ever had long strings of seaweed that wouldn't chew?? gross), and the service is quick. Lots of interesting rolls, try the Cherry Blossom, and plenty of sake.  Prices are okay too. Check it out
author: Tyler S.

description: This place is always playing J-pop to keep the Japanese-ness, which I like. The quality of the fish is good, but the fish:rice ratio is too much fish and too little rice. So I felt like I was eating sashimi more than sushi, but it was still good. The service is good too. I would eat here again.
author: Emy s.
